    <item>
      <title>Leading Hezbollah commander and key Israel target killed in Syria</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/hezbollah-commander-killed-israel-mustafa-badreddine</link>
      <description><p>Mustafa Badreddine, dubbed the ‘untraceable ghost’, had fought against Israel for decades and was killed in an explosion in Damascus</p><p>Hezbollah has confirmed its military commander, Mustafa Badreddine, was killed in Syria this week in what it described as a “major explosion” at Damascus airport.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>Media reports in Lebanon and Israel quickly suggested the blast had been caused by an Israeli airstrike, a suggestion to which Hezbollah gave weight, announcing it was investigating whether a “missile or artillery strike” had been responsible.<br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/hezbollah-commander-killed-israel-mustafa-badreddine">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Facebook trends: Zuckerberg invites top conservatives to talk and denies bias</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk</link>
      <description><p>As Facebook battles a report accusing it of suppressing conservative news, CEO says he plans to ‘invite leading conservatives ... to share their point of view’</p><p>Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has announced that he plans to invite “leading conservatives and people from across the political spectrum” to talk with him about accusations of political bias at the social media company.</p><p>Zuckerberg made the announcement Thursday evening in a <a href="https://www.facebook.com/zuck/posts/10102830259184701">Facebook post</a> that continued to deny the allegations of bias and the claim that the Facebook trending topics team suppresses conservative news. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>John Major: EU leave campaign at risk of ‘divisive’ immigration stance</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/john-major-eu-leave-campaigners-risk-turning-into-ukip</link>
      <description><p>Former prime minister will tell leaders of Brexit side that heavy emphasis on issue could lead to them ‘morphing into Ukip’</p><p>Sir John Major will tell those leading the campaign for Britain to leave the EU that they risk morphing into Ukip through their heavy emphasis on immigration.</p><p>In a speech on Friday that will be seen as a thinly veiled criticism of Boris Johnson, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/apr/19/michael-goves-points-based-system-immigration-fantasy">Michael Gove</a> and other senior Tory leave supporters, the former prime minister will accuse the anti-EU camp of crossing the line with its arguments in a way that risks dividing communities.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/john-major-eu-leave-campaigners-risk-turning-into-ukip">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Michael Temer takes reins as Brazil's president with pledge to rebuild country</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/michel-temer-brazil-president-rebuild-impeachment</link>
      <description><p>Dilma Rousseff’s suspension in impeachment vote hands power to ex-deputy who has promised unity while installing all-male, conspicuously white cabinet</p><p>Brazil’s interim president, Michel Temer, has unveiled an all-male, conspicuously white cabinet to run one of the world’s most ethnically diverse nations as he promised to restore confidence in Latin America’s biggest economy.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/the-guardian-view-on-dilma-rousseffs-impeachment-the-political-system-should-be-on-trial-not-one-woman">The Guardian view on Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment: the political system should be on trial, not one woman | Editorial</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/michel-temer-brazil-president-rebuild-impeachment">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Typhoon jets intercept Russian planes that committed 'act of aggression'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/13/typhoon-jets-intercept-russian-planes-that-committed-act-of-aggression</link>
      <description><p>RAF fighters based in Estonia headed off three military aircraft that approached Baltic skies without identifying themselves, says defence secretary</p><p>British fighter jets were scrambled to intercept three Russian aircraft approaching the Baltic skies in the first such intervention as part of their latest mission to keep airspace there secure, the defence ministry has said.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/17/raf-fighters-intercept-two-russian-bombers-uk-airspace">RAF jets intercept two Russian bombers nearing UK airspace</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/13/typhoon-jets-intercept-russian-planes-that-committed-act-of-aggression">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>US supreme court blocks Alabama execution amid dementia claim</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/us-supreme-court-blocks-alabama-execution-amid-dementia-claim</link>
      <description><p> Divided bench refuses to intervene after another court granted a stay to determine whether Vernon Madison, 65, can understand his death sentence</p><p>A divided US supreme court blocked the execution of an Alabama inmate to let a lower court review claims that strokes and dementia had left him incompetent to understand his death sentence.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/23/freed-alabama-death-row-inmate-im-at-peace-with-myself-are-they-at-peace">Freed Alabama death row inmate: 'I'm at peace with myself. Are they at peace?'</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/us-supreme-court-blocks-alabama-execution-amid-dementia-claim">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>US navy strips officer of command over capture of 10 sailors by Iran</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/13/us-navy-strips-officer-of-command-over-capture-of-10-sailors-by-iran</link>
      <description><p> Group wandered into Iranian territorial waters in the Persian Gulf and were held for 15 hours before intervention by US secretary of state secured release</p><p>A US navy officer has been stripped of his command over the capture by Iran of 10 American sailors who <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/12/iran-detains-two-us-navy-ships-persian-gulf">wandered into its territorial waters</a>.</p><p>In a statement on Thursday the navy said it had lost confidence in Commander Eric Rasch, who was the executive officer of the squadron that included the 10 sailors at the time of the January incident. He was responsible for the training and readiness of the more than 400 sailors in the unit.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/13/us-navy-strips-officer-of-command-over-capture-of-10-sailors-by-iran">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/13/eurovision-ireland-nicky-byrne-westlife-fails-make-final</link>
      <description><p>Former Westlife singer knocked out in semi-final in Stockholm where he performed his song Sunlight </p><p>Ireland’s Nicky Byrne has failed to qualify for the Eurovision song contest’s grand final.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>The former Westlife singer performed his song Sunlight at Thursday night’s semi-final in Stockholm, Sweden, where he was one of 18 acts competing for the last 10 places in the final.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/13/eurovision-ireland-nicky-byrne-westlife-fails-make-final">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Donald Trump supporters are not the bigots the left likes to demonise | John Harris</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/donald-trump-supporters-bigots-left-demonise</link>
      <description>It is time to stop the hysterical moralising and try to understand why mainstream US politics is so unappealing<p>Last Tuesday, at about 3pm, I parked my rental car outside a polling station in the suburbs of Indianapolis, and began to talk to the droves of people going in and out. There was only one subject I really wanted to hear about: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump">Donald Trump</a>, and his jaw-dropping progress to being the presumptive Republican nominee.</p><p>As he said himself, a win in the state of Indiana would seal the deal, and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/03/trump-wins-indiana-primary-us-election-2016">so it proved</a>: he got 53% of the vote, which triggered the exit of his two supposed rivals. Meanwhile, the global liberal left seemed to be once again working itself into a lather, which was easily translatable: how awful that a man routinely described using all the boo-words progressives can muster – misogynist, racist, fascist, xenophobe, or <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/03/george-clooney-donald-trump-is-a-xenophobic-fascist">“xenophobic fascist”</a>, as George Clooney understatedly <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/03/george-clooney-donald-trump-is-a-xenophobic-fascist">put it</a> – could now be a resident of the political mainstream, and a serious contender for president.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/donald-trump-supporters-bigots-left-demonise">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Kristen Stewart on Twilight fame: ‘I didn’t have a fully-lived life’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/13/kristen-stewart-twilight-fame-cannes-2016</link>
      <description><p>The star of two films at Cannes has discussed living in the media spotlight as a teenager and how she chooses to work with directors with ‘reckless intentions’</p><p>Few actors have made the transition from blockbuster lead to arthouse darling with such finesse as Kristen Stewart. The star, who shot to fame with the Twilight franchise in her teens, appears in two films at this year’s Cannes film festival: Woody Allen’s Cafe Society and Personal Shopper, her second film with French director Olivier Assayas – the first, Clouds of Sils Maria, made her the first American woman to win a Cesar award. <br></p><p>Speaking to promote Cafe Society at the festival, Stewart spoke of her respect and admiration for both directors, and her happiness in France, praising “the risk taken that’s different from why people make movies in the States”. She was eager to work with film-makers with “reckless intentions”, she said, adding: “I feel like there’s something psychic that happens when people are drawn to each other to make something. And I have so much faith in that that I will always follow it. And I will definitely make a few missteps and a few bad movies and things that aren’t so sure.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/13/kristen-stewart-twilight-fame-cannes-2016">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Successful women: it’s not only what they do, but what they don’t | Gaby Hinsliff</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/successful-women-pursuit-perfection</link>
      <description>As girls we are taught to do our best and to please others. But the pursuit of perfection has a dark side<p>Do less. Sleep more. Be gentle with yourself. Granted, it’s not exactly a thrusting mantra for success. No minor public school would choose it for a motto, and it’s hardly the stuff of a bestselling time-management book. What ambitious person wants to be told that actually there are only 24 hours in a day, and that sometimes the best way to squeeze more out of them is to stop trying so dementedly hard?</p><p>So it was easy to scoff at the sight of the recently reformed workaholic Arianna Huffington piously advising Hillary Clinton last week to <a href="http://uk.businessinsider.com/arianna-huffington-hillary-clinton-politics-democrat-presidential-2016-4?r=US&amp;IR=T" title="">stop “trying to do everything”</a> and make room for something called “self-care”. Seriously? Right now?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/successful-women-pursuit-perfection">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>English Heritage project aims to preserve war objectors' graffiti</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/first-world-war-objectors-graffiti-project-richmond-castle</link>
      <description><p>Fragile walls at Richmond Castle bear rare first-hand testimonial from men who refused to serve in first world war</p><p>In 1916 a conscientious objector, condemned by a tribunal for refusing to serve in the first world war, took up a pencil and very neatly explained his plight on the whitewashed wall of his cell in Richmond Castle in Yorkshire.</p><p>“‘I Percy F Goldsbrough of Mirfield was brought up from Pontefract on Friday August 11 1916 and put in this cell for refusing to be made into a soldier,” he wrote.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/first-world-war-objectors-graffiti-project-richmond-castle">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>When rail companies claim their trains are ‘on time’ – but you know they aren’t</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/13/rail-companies-trains-on-time-delays-cancellations-punctuality</link>
      <description>Angered by delays and cancellations, and claims that 82% of his trains were on time, Matt Steel kept a detailed record of his travels. The real punctuality figure? Just 37%<p>It all started when I was glancing idly at a Southern Railway performance poster while waiting for a delayed train. The posters are displayed around the network and proudly demonstrate how rail companies have hit their target for service performance – or at least how they have run close to it. But as I stared at the poster I wondered how more than 80% of trains were supposedly running on time, yet my experience was nothing like that.</p><p>At first I thought a couple of bad days on the trains were clouding my perception, and in reality most trains were running on time. But it didn’t ring true, so from the beginning of 2016 I started to keep a record of my journeys, comparing the time I should have arrived at my destinations with when I actually did (or in some cases failed to).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/13/rail-companies-trains-on-time-delays-cancellations-punctuality">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Taking children on holiday in term time: the issue that won't go away</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/taking-children-on-holiday-in-term-time-the-issue-that-wont-go-away</link>
      <description><p>One parent is awaiting an appeal over fines for taking his children out of school, and thousands more have already paid £60 penalties. Are families ‘held to ransom’ - and should the government act? </p><p>Ahead of <a href="http://www.jmppartnership.com/school-fines-parents-must-decide/">a high court ruling on the case of a parent who was fined after taking his children on holiday during term time</a>, a travel money provider claims tour operators are “holding parents to ransom” by doubling the costs of family holidays during the summer break. <br tabindex="-1"></p><p>Businessman John Platt will learn tomorrow (13 May) the outcome of his ongoing dispute with Isle of Wight Council, which took him to court in October 2015 after failing to pay a £120 fine for taking his children out of school for a family holiday to Disneyworld Florida. Although <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/education/2015/oct/16/father-overturns-120-fine-taking-daughter-term-time-holiday">the fine was overturned in the magistrates court</a>, the council has appealed to the high court, challenging the decision and seeking clarification on the law.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/taking-children-on-holiday-in-term-time-the-issue-that-wont-go-away">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Premier League: 10 things to look out for this weekend</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/13/premier-league-10-things-to-look-out-for-this-weekend</link>
      <description><p>Can Arsenal finish above Tottenham once more, will Spurs take advantage of Newcastle’s relegation and can Southampton secure European football?</p><p>An optimistic reading of Arsenal’s season might start with emphasis on how they were the least wobbly and underachieving of the supposed Big Four this season – Manchester City, Manchester United and Chelsea should all finish below them, barring an unlikely result against Aston Villa at the Emirates on Sunday. Of greater significance to the club’s fans, increasingly jaded by the trumpeting of “stable” top-four finishes, would be the chance to steal second place from Tottenham and finish above their rivals for the 21st season in succession. In lots of ways it would be aburdly undeserved. Arsenal have been out of the title race for a couple of months and though their football has purred at times, it has rarely thrilled in the manner of Tottenham’s. But Arsène Wenger knows how to engineer strong finishes to a campaign, even when – <em>especially</em> when, his detractors might say – there is nothing much to play for. Victory over a notoriously inept and long-doomed Villa ought to be a given, while Spurs might find things tougher against another relegated but less ragged side in Newcastle. In a week in which Arsenal have suffered more injury woe with news that <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/arsenal-danny-welbeck-nine-months-out-knee-surgery">Danny Welbeck faces nine months on the sidelines</a>, recent returnees Jack Wilshere (who impressed <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/08/manchester-city-arsenal-premier-league-match-report">at Manchester City last weekend</a>) and Santi Cazorla have a chance to decorate the final match of another unsatisfactory season. <strong>Tom Davies</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/13/premier-league-10-things-to-look-out-for-this-weekend">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>It’s not meant to end like this, Ozzy. You’re the Prince of Darkness</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/lostinshowbiz/2016/may/13/sharon-ozzy-osbourne-divorce-hairdresser</link>
      <description><p>Ozzy Osbourne’s alleged affair with his hairdresser – and the way that Sharon rumbled him – is enough to shake your faith in love, marriage – and even reality TV<br><br></p><p>You can never accuse Ozzy and Sharon Osbourne of dodging the zeitgeist. If popular culture is celebrating something – be it heavy metal or reality TV or Louis Walsh’s big, dumb, competition-winner of a face – you can guarantee that you’ll find the Osbournes somewhere in the foreground, clattering into each other like wasps in a jar.</p><p>With this in mind, it should come as no surprise that they are at it again. Because this is 2016, a year culturally identified by beautiful unions in states of deep internal crisis. There was Jay Z and Beyoncé. There was Batman and Superman. And now, inevitably, there is <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/ozzy-osbourne-marriage-end-sober-drugs">Ozzy and Sharon Osbourne</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/lostinshowbiz/2016/may/13/sharon-ozzy-osbourne-divorce-hairdresser">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I, Daniel Blake review: Ken Loach's welfare state polemic is blunt, dignified and brutally moving</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/i-daniel-blake-ken-loachs-welfare-state-polemic-is-blunt-dignified-and-brutally-moving</link>
      <description><p>There are shades of Dickens and Orwell in this emphatic drama about a disabled man strangled by the red tape of the benefits system</p><p>With this movie — <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/may/02/ken-loach-jimmys-hall-changes-mind-about-retirement">maybe his last, and maybe not</a> — Ken Loach establishes himself yet further as the John Bunyan of contemporary British cinema. Based on research and interviews by the screenwriter Paul Laverty, this movie tells the fictional story of Daniel Blake, a middle-aged widower in the North East who can’t work or get benefits after a near-fatal heart attack, and the story is told with stark and fierce plainness: unadorned, unapologetic, even unevolved. Loach’s movie offends against the tacitly accepted rules of sophisticated good taste: subtlety, irony and indirection. The film is not objective, and perhaps the Loach and Laverty have signed up to Churchill’s maxim about not being neutral between the firemen and the fire.</p><p>Ken Loach will insist on behaving as if there really is something urgently wrong, and that we shouldn’t or needn’t get used to food banks as a fact of life; he portrays it all as something which we might actually do something about in the real world, as opposed to invoking injustice as an aesthetic gesture, or a flavour-ingredient of modern social realist fiction. Many are happy to concede the value of films like this set in the developing world, showing sympathetic people trying to retain their dignity while being hungry. But the same thing set in modern Britain gets dismissed with an embarrassed shrug as strident or hectoring, as if going hungry is impossible for British non-shirkers. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/i-daniel-blake-ken-loachs-welfare-state-polemic-is-blunt-dignified-and-brutally-moving">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>‘Movie blood tastes so good’ – on The Neon Demon set with Nicolas Winding Refn</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/movie-blood-tastes-so-good-on-the-neon-demon-set-with-nicolas-winding-refn</link>
      <description><p>In his first horror movie, Drive director Refn puts Elle Fanning through hell as a young model in LA. Ahead of the film’s premiere at Cannes, we go behind the scenes</p><p>In May 2015, in the basement of a haunted house in Silver Lake, Los Angeles, one woman chases another with murderous intent. Under deep red light, she wields a poker. At a staircase, they struggle. The second woman falls, holding a gleaming Psycho-style kitchen knife. There is silence.</p><p>“Let’s do one more.” A few feet away, Nicolas Winding Refn looks up from scene 118, take four of his film, The Neon Demon. The crew unfreeze, a dozen figures in headphones. The women wander back to where they had started. The poker was carried by actor Abbey Lee, the knife by body double Joanna Bennett. Lee wears a white trouser suit, Bennett a ruched white dress. She is identical in every way to the film’s star, Elle Fanning, who watches nearby: same dress, same long blonde hair, the same tiny coloured jewels around their eyes. For a moment, they stand beside each other.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/movie-blood-tastes-so-good-on-the-neon-demon-set-with-nicolas-winding-refn">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Look out, Katie Hopkins, Azealia Banks is on the mic</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2016/may/12/azealia-banks-zayn-malik-katie-hopkins-one-direction</link>
      <description><p>The rapper was axed by a UK festival after a Twitter fight with Zayn Malik this week – it could be the start of a new career as a tabloid columnist</p><p>Our thoughts at this difficult time must be passed to part-time musician turned full-time Steve Brookstein Twitter account tribute act Azealia Banks, who has <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/azealia-banks-axed-uk-music-festival-zayn-malik-twitter" title="">been dropped by a London festival</a> that she was due to headline next month, all because she happens to be an objectively terrible person with no redeeming qualities.</p><p>Chances are you already know the events that kicked this all off. Banks initially claimed that Zayn Malik had plagiarised a video of hers, then, when he later tweeted something vague and unrelated at nobody in particular, launched into a vicious and sustained attack – both racist and homophobic – that lasted for several hours, expanded to take in the entire British music industry, then collapsed in on itself in a series of exhausted, strangulated yelps. The tweets have since been deleted, but the damage had already been done.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2016/may/12/azealia-banks-zayn-malik-katie-hopkins-one-direction">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Peaky Blinders recap: series three, episode two – enter Paddy Considine the creep</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/peaky-blinders-recap-series-three-episode-two-enter-paddy-considine-the-creep</link>
      <description><p>The devil wears a dog collar and despoils children … did Tommy Shelby just meet his ultimate adversary in Considine’s Father John Hughes?</p><p>Before this series started I interviewed creator Steven Knight, who told me that “things would come back to bite the Shelby gang”. And so it came to pass, as this episode ended with Grace lying wounded in her husband’s arms as Polly ran desperately for an ambulance and Arthur and John beat the living hell out of the Neapolitan assassin called in to do the job. </p><p>As to how serious Grace’s injury is – I’m not sure. She’s always seemed pretty unkillable; I predict an Adrian from Rocky-style coma for much of the season. Still, it was a great climax to a strong episode as Tommy’s constantly spinning plates – Shelby business, Russian business, Grace business, Economic League business – threatened to overwhelm him once and for all. There’s a point in every series of Peaky Blinders where it seems that Tommy has bitten off more than he can chew, yet somehow he always manages to carve a path through. This time, I’m not so sure he can. There’s a lot at stake – and, judging by the conversation between Grand Duke Leon and his formidable wife, more than even Tommy knows.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/peaky-blinders-recap-series-three-episode-two-enter-paddy-considine-the-creep">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Stone Roses: All For One review – lacking the stardust of the band's peak</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/the-stone-roses-all-for-one-review</link>
      <description><p>The Manchester band’s first music in 21 years will please the faithful, but those who crave the group’s true magic are unlikely to feel fulfilled </p><p>The message from the band wasn’t exactly overflowing with detail: “The Stone Roses will release a new single tonight at 8pm,” it said. Well, they always could be a bit terse.</p><p>Yet it said enough. After the Twitter rumours, <a href="http://www.nme.com/blogs/nme-blogs/the-stone-roses-is-the-third-coming-on-the-horizon">the snaps of band members hurriedly entering Paul Epworth’s north London recording studio</a> and a series of lemon posters erected in their hometown of Manchester, we’re finally here: All For One is the first new material from the Stone Roses in 21 years. And on paper, it has plenty of Roses touchstones: psychedelic vocals, a brilliant Squire solo that doesn’t overstay its welcome and a lyrical theme of solidarity – “All for one, one for all/If we all join hands we’ll make a wall” – that harks back to their rave roots. It’s surprisingly rocking – Reni’s drums flinging it along at a frantic, clattering pace – and the chorus will be bellowed loudly in fields by many a middle-aged man this summer.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/the-stone-roses-all-for-one-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/women-sexual-harrassment-sexism-deescalation</link>
      <description><p>Women shoulder the burden of keeping quiet amid harassment and casual misogyny: ‘If you say something, you’re a troublemaker’</p><p>I was in my early 20s and home for the winter holidays. Family friends had come round for dinner. I was in the living room with one of them, a father with three grown sons around my age. I had known them all my whole life; their smiles evoked memories of beach picnics and summer ball games. <br></p><p>My mother was in the kitchen. I don’t know where my sisters were.     <item>
      <title>BBC, ITV and migration spark shadows of outrage in Westminster</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-itv-and-migration-spark-shadows-of-outrage-in-westminster</link>
      <description><p>As the big news of the day proves to be not so big after all, MPs find themselves all worked up with nowhere to go<br></p><p>Maria Eagle was outraged. Outraged that there was almost nothing to be outraged about. After months of the “End of the World as We Know It” doomsday predictions, the culture secretary finally <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-john-whittingdale-white-paper-star-pay-board">published his white paper on the BBC</a>, and it was, if not quite business as usual, then not nearly so bad as feared. Strictly Come Dancing had been saved for the nation. There could be only one explanation; the leftwing luvvies had managed to nobble John Whittingdale.</p><p>“The fact that most of the secretary of state’s wilder proposals appear to have been watered down, dumped or delayed by the government, of which he is a member, is a reflection of his diminishing influence and lack of clout,” said the shadow culture secretary, her voice bristling with contempt. “There is no point in the secretary of state denying that he has been overruled by the prime minister and the chancellor.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-itv-and-migration-spark-shadows-of-outrage-in-westminster">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Everton hope to tempt Ronald Koeman with lure of record transfer budget</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/everton-ronald-koeman-roberto-martinez-goodison-park-</link>
      <description>• Roberto Martínez fired after three seasons in the job<br />• Blues draw up a working shortlist of Dutchmen<br /><p>Everton want Ronald Koeman to succeed Roberto Martínez and hope to lure the Southampton coach with the promise of the biggest transfer budget in their history.</p><p>Farhad Moshiri, Everton’s new major shareholder, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/roberto-martinez-sacked-everton" title="">sacked Martínez on Thursday</a> and has earmarked Southampton’s manager as his preferred replacement. The British-Iranian billionaire faces a challenge to prise the 53-year-old from St&nbsp;Mary’s, however, even with Koeman yet to commit to a new contract and having just over 12 months remaining on his deal.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/everton-ronald-koeman-roberto-martinez-goodison-park-">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><ul><li>Wallabies star to become highest paid player in England with £1.5m deal<br></li><li>Beale’s 60 Test caps mean he will still be eligible to play for Australia</li></ul><p>Wallabies star Kurtley Beale has reportedly signed a deal with Wasps which will make him the highest paid player in England.     <item>
      <title>Dick Pound promises IOC will not derail Tokyo 2020 corruption inquiry</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/dick-pound-ioc-tokyo-2020-corruption</link>
      <description><p>• French prosecutors investigating payments from Tokyo 2020 bid<br>• ‘We would not try to discourage them from where the trail led,’ says Pound</p><p>Dick Pound, the veteran IOC member, has said French prosecutors should follow the trail of corruption “wherever it leads” after they <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/french-financial-prosecutors-confirm-investigation-into-tokyo-2020-bid-olympics-black-tidings">confirmed an investigation</a> into alleged seven-figure payments from the successful Tokyo 2020 Olympic bid to a secret account linked to the son of the disgraced former IAAF president Lamine Diack.</p><p>French prosecutors confirmed they were examining a string of potential offences including aggravated money laundering, corruption and bribery involving more than $2m (£1.4m) in suspicious payments apparently made to a bank account linked to Papa Massata Diack, the marketing consultant whose father was an influential International Olympic Committee member for 14 years.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/dick-pound-ioc-tokyo-2020-corruption">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Russian doctors and athletes ‘switched urine samples’ at Sochi Olympics</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/russian-doctors-athletes-evaded-doping-tests</link>
      <description>• Former head of Russia’s national anti-doping lab admits to cheating tests<br />• Grigory Rodchenkov tells New York Times of widespread conspiracy<p>The former head of the Russian Anti-Doping Agency has revealed his part in an astonishing state-run doping programme before and during the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, which included supplying banned performance-enhancing substances to at least 15 medal winners and substituting tainted urine samples with clean ones during the Games so that they passed doping tests. The International Olympic Committee described the accusations as “very worrying” and called for them to be investigated immediately by the World Anti-Doping Agency .</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/french-financial-prosecutors-confirm-investigation-into-tokyo-2020-bid-olympics-black-tidings">French financial prosecutors confirm investigation into Tokyo 2020 bid</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/russian-doctors-athletes-evaded-doping-tests">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>Alex Goode can be the key man in a game likely to be dominated by two physical defences, while Sarries need to target Maxime Machenaud and Eddy Ben Arous<p>I think Saracens can beat Racing 92 in the European Rugby Champions Cup final on Saturday and I hope they do. My heart says they will do it as I would like to see an English team become European champions for the first time since Wasps in 2007.       <title>Rafael Benítez tempted by Newcastle stay after ‘productive’ talks</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/rafael-benitez-newcastle-tempted-productive-talks</link>
      <description>• Manager to demand written assurances of promises made in negotiations<br />• Benítez has relegation clause in contract which allows him to leave<p>Rafael Benítez is strongly tempted by the challenge of leading Newcastle out of the Championship but despite “productive” talks with Lee Charnley, the newly relegated club’s managing director, on Thursday afternoon, much needs to be negotiated before any decision is reached.</p><p>It is understood that Benítez will demand written assurances of promises made during the ongoing discussions but, with his own immediate future seeming inextricably linked to that of the Spaniard, Charnley has a keen interest in persuading Steve McClaren’s successor to ignore the break option in his three-year contract.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/rafael-benitez-newcastle-tempted-productive-talks">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Sri Lanka produce decent Test players despite system, says Kumar Sangakkara</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/sri-lanka-kumar-sangakkara-headingley-first-test-england</link>
      <description>• ‘Three-day cricket is not played to a standard that is acceptable’<br />• Headingley hosts first Test against England from Thursday<p>Kumar Sangakkara has bemoaned the domestic system in Sri Lanka that, in his view, means the country’s cricketers learning their trade at international level and makes their upcoming Test series<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/stuart-broad-england-jake-ball-sri-lanka-cricket" title=""> with England a battle to be competitive</a>.</p><p>Sangakkara, scorer of 12,400 Test runs, was part of the side that in 2014 capitalised on England’s angst following their Ashes whitewash in Australia to secure a 1-0 series victory under the then captain Mahela Jayawardene, with a tense 100-run win at Headingley, scene of next week’s first Test, that <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/jun/24/sri-lanka-second-test-one-ball-left-end-england-resistance" title="">was secured off the penultimate ball of the match</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/sri-lanka-kumar-sangakkara-headingley-first-test-england">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Daniil Kvyat pledges ‘answers on the track’ following Red Bull F1 demotion</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/daniil-kvyat-red-bull-demotion-toro-rosso-max-verstappen-f1</link>
      <description>• Kvyat was dropped to junior Toro Rosso team and replaced by Max Verstappen<br />• ‘There was no real explanation to be honest. The decision was a bit of a shock’<p>A bitterly disappointed Daniil Kvyat has said he received no explanation for his sudden <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/05/red-bull-drop-daniil-kvyat-f1-max-verstappen" title="">dropping from the Red Bull team</a>, only four races into the Formula One season. Kvyat, who finished ahead of his senior Red Bull team-mate Daniel Ricciardo in last year’s championship and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/17/chinese-grand-prix-f1-nico-rosberg" title="">won a podium place</a> in last month’s Chinese Grand Prix, has been sent back to his old Toro Rosso team and replaced by the 18-year-old sensation Max Verstappen.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/lewis-hamilton-formula-one-f1-mercedes-nico-rosberg-mclaren">Lewis Hamilton believes experience will help him overcome F1 setbacks</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/daniil-kvyat-red-bull-demotion-toro-rosso-max-verstappen-f1">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Novak Djokovic shaken at Italian Open but Andy Murray eases through</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/andy-murray-beats-jeremy-chardy-italian-open-david-goffin-tennis</link>
      <description>• Djokovic recovers from first-set bagel to beat Thomaz Bellucci<br />• World No1 faces Rafael Nadal in quarter-finals; Murray plays David Goffin<p>They say nothing lasts for ever in the Eternal City but this was ridiculous. In a day of fantasy tennis that might have been scripted by Federico Fellini, the world No1, Novak Djokovic, considered to be approaching invincibility in his sport, went 33 minutes and 47 seconds before he could raise his arms in mock triumph to celebrate winning a game against the world No37, Thomaz Bellucci, in the third round of the Italian Open.</p><p>At that point, the Serb had won only 15 points to the Brazilian’s 34 and was struggling to come to terms with having been bagelled for the first time since Roger Federer kept him scoreless in the first set in Cincinnati five years ago.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/andy-murray-beats-jeremy-chardy-italian-open-david-goffin-tennis">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Luke Gale leads Castleford to crushing victory over Leeds Rhinos</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/leeds-castleford-super-league-match-report</link>
      <description>• Leeds Rhinos 12-52 Castleford Tigers<p>So, where now for Leeds Rhinos? The obvious answer is the Qualifiers and a relegation battle in the second half of this most extraordinary of seasons, and this was a performance that prompted yet more questions about the spectacular demise of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/oct/02/leeds-rhinos-st-helens-super-league-semi-final-match-report" title="">last year’s treble winners</a>.</p><p>The more optimistic Leeds fan would have argued that a combined losing margin of just 12 points from their last two games suggested the defending champions were slowly getting their act together. But this? This was a complete annihilation, and the firmest evidence yet that Leeds are destined for the bottom four.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/leeds-castleford-super-league-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Serena Williams falls ill after eating dog food ... then wins at Italian Open</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/serena-williams-dog-food-italian-open</link>
      <description><ul><li>World No1 samples dish meant for her pet dog Chip</li><li>Goes on to beat Christian McHale in third round in Rome</li></ul><p>The benefits of special diets for athletes have been well documented, but Serena Williams may have taken things too far on Wednesday when she decided to sample her pet dog’s dinner.</p><p>Williams is playing in the Italian Open, and her hotel had prepared a special menu for her Yorkshire terrier, Chip, including a tempting salmon and rice dish. The world No1 sampled some of it, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IRrze_N9IpI">telling fans on Snapchat</a>: “I ate a spoonful. Don’t judge me.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/serena-williams-dog-food-italian-open">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/tim-wellens-win-stage-six-giro-ditalia-lotto-soudal-tom-dumoulin</link>
      <description>• Belgian rider sprints home following initial five-man breakaway<br />• Team Giant-Alpecin’s Tom Dumoulin retains Maglia Rosa<p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/11/andre-greipel-wins-giro-ditalia-stage-five">André Greipel wins Giro d’Italia stage five but Tom Dumoulin maintains lead</a> </p><p>Belgium’s Tim Wellens broke away alone to win the sixth stage of the Giro d’Italia as the peloton negotiated the first real climbs of the race on Thursday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/tim-wellens-win-stage-six-giro-ditalia-lotto-soudal-tom-dumoulin">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sunderland relegate Newcastle and Norwich – Football Weekly Extra</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/audio/2016/may/12/sunderland-relegate-newcastle-norwich-football-weekly-extra-podcast</link>
      <description><p>Sam Allardyce saves his Premier League skin again. Plus, the battle for the Champions League spots, John Terry’s Stamford Bridge barbecue and the curious case of Joey Barton’s Championship winner’s medal </p><p>On today’s<strong> Football Weekly Extra</strong>, <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/acjimbo">AC Jimbo</a></strong> is joined by the triple threat of <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/bglendenning">Barry Glendenning</a></strong>, <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/john_ashdown">John Ashdown</a></strong> and <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/greggbakowski">Gregg Bakowski</a></strong> to look back on <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report">Sunderland’s victory at Everton</a>, a result which <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/11/sam-allardyce-sunderland-escape-route-everton-rafael-benitez">confirmed the relegations of both Newcastle and Norwich</a>. <a href="http://www.claretandhugh.info/wp-content/uploads/Big-Sam_800x400-800x380.jpg">Oh, Big Sam, how could you</a>?</p><p>With the top and the bottom of the Premier League therefore sorted, the drama of the final weekend involves <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/liverpool-manchester-united-hopes-european-hopes">the Champions League spots</a>. Will <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/09/tottenham-finishing-above-arsenal-good-feeling-harry-kane">Arsenal pip Spurs</a> to second place? Will it be United or City who finish fourth? Or will <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/west-ham-david-sullivan-poor-judgement-supporters">West Ham inflict yet damage pain on United’s coach</a>? (That’s LVG, people).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/audio/2016/may/12/sunderland-relegate-newcastle-norwich-football-weekly-extra-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jason Day shoots record-equalling round at Players Championship</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett</link>
      <description>• Shane Lowry and Justin Rose two behind leader at Sawgrass<br />• Jordan Spieth level-par 72, Danny Willett signs for 70<p>The angst Jordan Spieth suffered by virtue of closing his opening round at the Players Championship with a seven, the one number that may bring him out in a cold sweat, surely intensified with a glance towards one of the his playing partners. Jason Day, who has succeeded Spieth as the world No1, endorsed his status once more with a course record-equalling 63. Day had birdie putts at all 18 holes.</p><p>As Day tapped in for birdie at the 9th, their 18th, Spieth was about to three putt for a double bogey. Spieth’s frustration at a 72 on a day of generally excellent scoring was compounded by that seven; the same scorecard aberration that fatally undermined his hopes of defending the Masters, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/11/danny-willett-masterrs-2016-jordan-spieth-lee-westood" title="">owing to a capitulation at Augusta National’s 12th hole</a>. Spieth later insisted his Thursday score did not appropriately represent his performance. “I really only had two bad swings today,” he said. “I’m hitting the ball great.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Kenya’s Olympic participation in doubt after Wada recommendation</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/kenya-olympic-doubt-wada-non-compliant</link>
      <description>• African country declared non-compliant by review committee<br />• IOC will decide whether to ban Kenya from the Rio Games<p>The World Anti-Doping Agency’s compliance review committee has recommended Kenya be declared non-compliant, casting doubt on the country’s participation in this summer’s Olympic Games.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/07/kenya-handed-extension-anti-doping-code-olympics-iaaf-wada" title="">Having missed two deadlines</a> to show it was addressing serious worries about its anti-doping efforts, Kenya passed legislation last month to create a new national anti-doping agency. However that has not been enough to satisfy Wada.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/kenya-olympic-doubt-wada-non-compliant">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/olympics-general">Olympics</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/kenya">Kenya</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/africa">Africa</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/world">World news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/athletics">Athletics</category>

    <item>
      <title>Why Brexit would be the perfect gift for Vladimir Putin | Garry Kasparov</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/brexit-perfect-gift-vladimir-putin-eu</link>
      <description>An EU without Britain is exactly what the Russian president wants: a weakened institution with less power to confront his assaults on Europe’s borders<p>Politics often makes for strange bedfellows. Far-right parties in the UK and across Europe push for anything that will weaken the European Union – a goal shared by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/vladimir-putin" title="">Vladimir Putin</a> and Donald Trump. This week, their fellow Brexiteer Boris Johnson went as far as to repeat the Kremlin line that Europe is <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/09/boris-johnson-cameron-cant-cut-immigration-and-stay-in-eu" title="">partly to blame for Putin’s ongoing invasion of Ukraine</a>.</p><p>One does not expect clear policy statements from Trump or Johnson, but Putin’s reasoning is irrefutable. His goal is to weaken the institutions, including Nato and the EU, that could thwart his neo-Soviet ambitions. The Kremlin was in mourning when Scotland narrowly voted to stay in the UK. Putin sees Europe as his enemy and wants his&nbsp;adversaries to be divided, smaller and weaker.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/brexit-perfect-gift-vladimir-putin-eu">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Tories’ BBC haters have been halted. Next, to Europe | Martin Kettle</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/tories-bbc-haters-halted-next-europe-david-cameron</link>
      <description>With today’s BBC white paper one national disaster has been narrowly averted. But David Cameron’s weak leadership on the EU could yet unleash another<p>Be very clear about the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-white-paper-key-points-john-whittingdale" title="">BBC white paper</a>. In almost any other country in the world this would not be happening at all. Beyond Britain the BBC is universally revered. It stands for excellence and independence; and because of that excellence and independence, it stands above all for reliability. There is no other engine of soft power to touch it on the planet.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-white-paper-key-points-john-whittingdale">BBC white paper: key points at a glance</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/tories-bbc-haters-halted-next-europe-david-cameron">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/public-leaders-network/2016/may/13/barnet-chief-executive-andrew-travers-voting-blunder</link>
      <description><p>Barnet’s chief executive, Andrew Travers, quickly resigned after last week’s voting fiasco. But perhaps the wider council is also to blame</p><p>Andrew Travers’ exit from the chief executive’s job at Barnet council after last Thursday’s voting <a href="https://www.barnet.gov.uk/citizen-home/news/Council-launches-investigation-into-election-problems.htmls">fiasco</a> was dramatic and swift.</p><p> But the Electoral Commission’s tests for a <a href="http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0007/141649/LGEW-MAY-RO-Part-A-role-and-responsibilities.pdf">returning officer</a> are rigorous and specific. The first is making it easy to vote. That wasn’t the case in the north London borough, where residents had to wait till 10.30 in the morning before polling stations opened with accurate lists.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/public-leaders-network/2016/may/13/barnet-chief-executive-andrew-travers-voting-blunder">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Marshall Marcus: The European Union Youth Orchestra cannot be strangled by European bureaucracy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/13/marshall-marcus-the-european-union-youth-orchestra-cannot-be-strangled</link>
      <description><p>The EUYO has announced its closure. Chief Executive Marshall Marcus explains why a 40-year-old institution that represents the best of pan-European creativity has been silenced</p><p>Amid the sagging plethora of Brexit conversations, real passion can often seem to be lacking among the EU’s top brass. Except however, when they talk about one particular enterprise: “<a href="http://www.euyo.eu/">The European Union Youth Orchestra</a> remains one of our most distinguished ambassadors … a potent symbol of our European Union.” (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/jean-claude-juncker">Jean-Claude Juncker</a>, EU Commission President). <br></p><p>“I was moved not simply by the beauty of the music they produced, but also by what they stand for: the EUYO perfectly embodies the power of being united in diversity,” (Juncker’s colleague <a href="http://www.europarl.europa.eu/the-president/en/">Martin Schulz</a>, European Parliament President). </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/13/marshall-marcus-the-european-union-youth-orchestra-cannot-be-strangled">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Better than expected - a reasonable and sensible compromise for the BBC</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2016/may/13/better-than-expected-a-reasonable-and-sensible-compromise-for-the-bbc</link>
      <description><p>Tony Hall has ensured that the wilder political demands have been shelved </p><p>The temptation to be triumphalist about the BBC reforms must be resisted. But let’s face it: the corporation appears to have emerged largely unscathed from the government’s so-called “major overhaul”.</p><p>Yes, there are far-reaching changes, notably the abolition of the BBC Trust and its replacement with a unitary board. Also, Ofcom will now be responsible for dealing with complaints about the corporation’s impartiality and accuracy.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2016/may/13/better-than-expected-a-reasonable-and-sensible-compromise-for-the-bbc">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Free speech is under attack, from Beijing to Istanbul | Timothy Garton Ash</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/free-speech-under-attack-beijing-istanbul</link>
      <description><p>Britain, the land of George Orwell, must stand up against this anti-liberal tide, and keep its government’s hands off the BBC</p><p>Wherever you look, free speech is under attack. In China, an independent-minded <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/17/chinese-journalist-disappears-fly-beijing-hong-kong">journalist disappears at the airport</a>, one of many to be detained, censored and intimidated. In Egypt, an Italian student researching for his Cambridge University doctorate is <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/26/giulio-regeni-parents-condemn-arrest-activist-in-cairo-egypt">found tortured and murdered</a>, while hundreds of bloggers and activists have been detained. In Turkey, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/06/turkish-journalist-can-dundar-escapes-attempted-shooting-outside-court">two prominent journalists are sentenced to five years’ imprisonment</a> for publishing an important story about covert Turkish arms deliveries to Syria, while two more receive <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/05/turkish-laugh-politicians-president-erdogan-prime-minister-resigned">two-year sentences for reprinting cartoons from Charlie Hebdo</a>. Since 2014 some <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/02/turkeys-justice-minister-defends-allowing-1845-insult-cases-to-go-ahead">1,845 suits have been filed</a> against people alleged to have “insulted” the thin-skinned Recep Tayyip Erdoğan.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/06/turkish-journalist-can-dundar-escapes-attempted-shooting-outside-court">Turkish journalist Can Dündar jailed after surviving gun attack</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/free-speech-under-attack-beijing-istanbul">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Paul Ryan and Donald Trump might say they're unified. But there's a bloody civil war on | Richard Wolffe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/paul-ryan-donald-trump-republican-unity-battle</link>
      <description><p>Don’t be fooled by the diplomatic words, because peace hasn’t broken out. The Republican power-brokers still loathe Trump, and Ryan is their standard bearer</p><p>When Donald Trump met with Paul Ryan in Washington on Thursday, you could say it was a meeting between the current and possibly future nominee of the Republican party. Or you could say it was a battle for the soul of the party, between a conservative reformer and nativist rabble-rouser.<br></p><p>The latter is how Ryan himself portrayed the debate when he torpedoed the orange flagship on CNN last week. Saying he “just wasn’t ready” to support Trump, the House speaker warned that Trump’s platform was not inclusive, presidential or, well, conservative.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/paul-ryan-donald-trump-republican-unity-battle">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Beyond buttocks: this Turner prize shortlist is cheeky and smart</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/12/beyond-buttocks-turner-prize-shortlist-cheeky-smart</link>
      <description><p>There’s no singing, no painting and not a video in sight. But we do have choo-choos, a live ant farm – and plenty of puzzles and games</p><p>This is a good and in some ways unexpected <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/12/turner-prize-shortlist-anthea-hamilton-michael-dean-helen-marten-josephine-pryde">Turner prize shortlist</a>. I have been expecting Helen Marten to appear for a couple of years – unless, as artists sometimes have, she declined to show until now. Last year was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/dec/07/turner-prize-2015-assemble-win-by-ignoring-art-market">Assemble’s moment</a>, and their inclusion heightened a debate about collective and socially engaged art that was worth having. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/12/turner-prize-shortlist-anthea-hamilton-michael-dean-helen-marten-josephine-pryde">Turner prize shortlist features buttocks sculpture and choo-choo-train ride</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/12/beyond-buttocks-turner-prize-shortlist-cheeky-smart">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Britain’s accountability problem – hospitals are just the start | Anne Perkins</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/hillsborough-hospitals-public-bodies</link>
      <description><p>If holding vital public bodies to account is a mark of a civilised, functioning democracy, we’re not in a good place</p><p>Margaret Aspinall, whose 18-year-old son James <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/apr/27/hillsborough-families-applauded-at-liverpool-vigil-inquest">died in the Hillsborough tragedy</a>, addressed a meeting in parliament on Tuesday. She spoke at the launch of Andy Burnham’s <a href="http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/andy-burnham-proposes-major-reforms-11313170">new campaign</a> for stronger police accountability. The parliamentary and health service ombudsman (PHSO) has just <a href="http://www.ombudsman.org.uk/reports-and-consultations/reports/health/a-report-of-investigations-into-unsafe-discharge-from-hospital">published a shaming report</a> on the way vulnerable patients are sometimes discharged from hospital. Earlier in the week, health thinktank <a href="http://www.kingsfund.org.uk/blog/2016/04/readiness-to-change">the King’s Fund</a> heard that there was a serious shortage of senior managers prepared to take on the thankless task of running an NHS trust.</p><p>Each of these is important in themselves. Each of these says something troubling about how public bodies are held to account.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/hillsborough-hospitals-public-bodies">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Vote Leave may sideline Nigel Farage, but it can’t live without him | Rafael Behr</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/vote-leave-campaign-nigel-farage</link>
      <description>At the heart of the leave campaign is a tension between belief in one set of arguments and recognition that it can only win using contradictory views<p>This really should be Nigel Farage’s moment, if not his finest hour then certainly his noisiest one. No one in British politics has a better claim to the credit – or blame – for steering the country into a referendum on European Union membership than the Ukip leader.</p><p>It was the prime minister who called the vote in acquiescence to pressure from his own MPs, but it was the Faragist culture war, waged from outside the Conservative party, that made David Cameron’s capitulation unavoidable. Ukip shook the can before Tory MPs handed it to Cameron for opening, thereby spraying himself and his party in a sticky political mess.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/vote-leave-campaign-nigel-farage">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Egyptian writer Ahmed Naji’s crime isn't what he wrote – it is that he is alive</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2016/may/12/pleas-release-egyptian-writer-ahmed-naji</link>
      <description><p>Over 600 Egyptian writers have signed a statement in support of the Egyptian author, who is serving a two-year sentence for ‘injuring public modesty’ with his graphic novel, The Use of Life</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/10/philip-roth-patti-smith-and-woody-allen-join-protest-at-jailing-of-egyptian-writer">Philip Roth, Patti Smith and Woody Allen join protest at jailing of Egyptian writer</a></li></ul><p>Ahmed Naji, 30, is a novelist and wide-ranging essayist. He is part of a group (a movement, maybe) of young artists who work across art forms and borders and are producing the most dynamic and innovative art coming out of Egypt. But, today, Naji is on day 86 of a two-year prison sentence.</p><p>The ostensible cause of his jailing is a striking graphic novel, <em>The Use of Life</em>, produced in collaboration with the artist Ayman Zorkani. It is a subtle exploration of the ennui of life in a dystopian city and shows a tremendous knowledge of the history and architecture of Cairo. It is also clearly rooted in classical Arabic literary idiom – including the classics’ straightforward descriptions of body parts and their uses.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2016/may/12/pleas-release-egyptian-writer-ahmed-naji">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The US spinoff’s mistaken valuation shows up what’s wrong with the BBC flagship. Where once the Beeb encouraged art for its own sake, here profit is king</p><p>I have to confess to sheer delight at the mistake made by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/11/antiques-roadshow-expert-mistake-school-art-project">a hapless Antiques Roadshow “expert”</a>. Examining a comically primitivist pot brought in for valuation on the popular and venerable television show, appraiser Stephen L Fletcher got quite excited. He identified it as a daring early modernist work from the 19th century. He even discerned “a little bit of, like, <a href="http://www.christies.com/features/Collecting-Picasso-Ceramics-7312-1.aspx">Pablo Picasso</a> going on here”.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/11/antiques-roadshow-expert-mistake-school-art-project">Antiques Roadshow expert mistakenly values school art project at $50,000</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2016/may/12/antiques-roadshows-jug-picasso-bbc">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I am dying and I want everyone to talk about it</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2016/may/12/i-am-dying-want-talk-family-carer-doctors-death</link>
      <description><p>This is a plea to my family, carer, doctors and specialists: start talking about death as much as you do about life. Is that too much to ask?</p><p>For 16 years I have known I’m terminally ill. I’ve had to come to terms with the fact I won’t grow old with my husband, or see my grandchildren become teenagers. I’ve seen my body change; I am slowly wasting away. I have faced the mental struggle of being told I’ve 18 months to live, only to see myself outlive the prognosis. I take 38 tablets every single day and rely on an oxygen tank to breathe. My spine is crumbling; I’ve shrunk by two inches. My skin is covered in painful psoriasis, and I have a growth in my stomach the size of a 30-week pregnancy.</p><p>And yet, despite this, my biggest challenge is trying to talk to you about the fact that soon, I will die. There’s something about death that people can’t face. We thrive on life; we celebrate it at every opportunity whether it’s a birthday or a christening. And yet, even though everyone who lives will die, death remains the elephant in the room. It’s a stigma, something we need to tiptoe around and leave to care professionals.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2016/may/12/i-am-dying-want-talk-family-carer-doctors-death">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A judge-shaming list is bad for justice | Joshua Rozenberg</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/judge-shaming-list-guardian-freedom-information-request-prince-of-wales-letters</link>
      <description>Judges shouldn’t be frightened to set precedents. A list of those that have ‘gone too far’ – including over a Guardian freedom of information request on the Prince of Wales’s letters – risks deterring justice<p>Was the UK supreme court’s judgment <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/mar/26/supreme-court-clears-way-release-secret-prince-charles-letters-black-spider-memos" title="">last year</a> allowing the Guardian to publish letters written to ministers by the Prince of Wales a “problematic” case?</p><p>It certainly caused problems for the judges who heard it over a 10-year period. They disagreed over whether to uphold the attorney general’s veto on a freedom of information request made by the reporter Rob Evans. As I <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/mar/26/prince-charles-letters-case-reinforces-profound-constitutional-principles" title="">noted at the time</a>, Lord Wilson even accused his fellow supreme court justices of undermining parliamentary sovereignty.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/judge-shaming-list-guardian-freedom-information-request-prince-of-wales-letters">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/law/judiciary">Judiciary</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/law/law">Law</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/media/theguardian">The Guardian</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/media/media">Media</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/media/medialaw">Media law</category>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:20:32 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/judge-shaming-list-guardian-freedom-information-request-prince-of-wales-letters</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/9b1d52ff54bc500b5ac6e4e3ab9cb361c6243148/1014_640_1421_852/1421.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=8f84a611edc61a8029f1b3b4f5af7985">

      <title>There’s nothing wrong with having a baby in your 70s | Aarathi Prasad</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/daljinder-kaur-baby-70s</link>
      <description>Any woman should be able to make good decisions about her body – and if Daljinder Kaur is strong enough to fulfil her parenting dream perhaps we should lay off<p>The birth of Armaan Singh Gill, a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/indian-woman-in-her-70s-gives-birth-to-healthy-baby-boy" title="">2kg boy, to Daljinder Kaur</a> was announced by Indian and international media this week. Though she has no birth certificate, Kaur, estimated to be 72, is thought to be the world’s oldest mother. Armaan was her first child. He was the result of her third round of IVF, using donor eggs and possibly donor sperm as well.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/indian-woman-in-her-70s-gives-birth-to-healthy-baby-boy">Indian woman in her 70s gives birth to healthy baby boy</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/daljinder-kaur-baby-70s">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>For Haredi Jews secular Zionism remains a religious heresy | Giles Fraser: Loose canon</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2016/may/12/for-haredi-jews-secular-zionism-remains-a-religious-heresy</link>
      <description><p>The continuing rejection of modern Zionism by some ultra-orthodox Jews disrupts the argument that anti-Zionism is always antisemitism</p><p>The walled neighbourhood of Mea Shearim is just a few minutes’ walk from the old city of Jerusalem. Built in 1874, it is home to Jerusalem’s Haredi or ultra-orthodox community – though that description is sometimes used as a term of abuse. The word Haredi is taken from the book of Isaiah and refers to those who tremble before God. A bit like the Quakers.</p><p>The Haredi regard themselves as no-compromise, Torah-faithful Jews, living out the word of God as best they can, until the coming of the messiah. The&nbsp;people who live here wear long black&nbsp;frock coats and broad-rimmed hats. Posters put up at the various entrances to the area demand modesty from visitors: long dresses and sleeves. Another poster declares: “No entry to Zionists”. Mea&nbsp;Shearim is home to some of the most fervently anti-Zionist Jews in the world.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2016/may/12/for-haredi-jews-secular-zionism-remains-a-religious-heresy">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>It lacks the glamour of saving Strictly – but the BBC’s new board must be resisted | Polly Toynbee</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/dont-let-strictly-climbdown-fool-you-bbc-isnt-safe</link>
      <description>Government-appointed board members, Ofcom-regulated, and the NAO auditing value for money? The fight to keep the BBC in licence-payers’ hands isn’t over<p>How hard will the BBC fight? How hard will <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/11/bbc-white-paper-john-whittingdale" title="">the public </a>fight for it? And the Lords and MPs? The danger is that “<a href="http://" title="">compromises</a>” in the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/10/bbc-white-paper-conservative-mps-independence" title="">white paper</a> are accepted as a “<a href="http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/bbc-stars-keep-pay-deals-secret-after-government-climbdown-qpk32dxmh" title="">climbdown</a>” and everyone breathes a sigh of relief.</p><p>Yet the white paper dangerously undermines the BBC’s independence and international credibility with a new governance arrangement that for the first time ever puts six government appointees in control of day-to-day editorial decision-making.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/dont-let-strictly-climbdown-fool-you-bbc-isnt-safe">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Angela Merkel is suddenly looking politically mortal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2016/may/12/angela-merkel-suddenly-looking-politically-mortal</link>
      <description><p>Will the German chancellor survive to serve another term? Should she?</p><p>Europe’s most important politician <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/10/iain-duncan-smith-cameron-let-germans-veto-emergency-brake">took a bit of a pasting from the Brexit camp this week</a> for allegedly throwing her weight around in David Cameron’s company. She has had a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/12/angela-merkel-elections-refugee-crisis-far-right">rough few months</a> since the Syrian refugee crisis hit Germany and is suddenly looking politically mortal. But does Angela Merkel deserve it? </p><p>Yes and mostly no. In these turbulent times we may miss her quietly steady hand when it’s no longer there to hold. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2016/may/12/angela-merkel-suddenly-looking-politically-mortal">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Woman made to wear heels to work: ‘This is a women’s rights issue’ – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/video/2016/may/11/woman-made-to-wear-heels-to-work-this-is-a-womens-rights-issue-video</link>
      <description><p>A woman who was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/11/receptionist-sent-home-pwc-not-wearing-high-heels-pwc-nicola-thorp">sent home from work unpaid on her first day</a> due to her refusal to wear heels says she will push for a petition she started to be debated in parliament. Nicola Thorp, 27, began the petition after she was told she had to wear 2-4in heels in her job as a receptionist as part of the dress code.       <title>Autism: getting lost in London – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/video/2016/may/11/autism-getting-lost-in-london-video</link>
      <description><p>Kane is 19 and has Asperger syndrome. He’s a student and lives at home with his family. His care worker challenged him to spend a day map-reading in London. He describes his reactions to uncertainty, complex and seemingly illogical decisions of where to go and why, combined with an overload of visual stimulation, noise and feeling singled out and stared at</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.autism.org.uk/TMI">Find out more about the National Autism Society’s Too Much Information campaign</a></li></ul> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/video/2016/may/11/autism-getting-lost-in-london-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/13/fracking-north-york-moors-gets-go-ahead-protests-kirby-misperton</link>

      <title>Tesco boss Dave Lewis paid £4.6m</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/13/tesco-boss-dave-lewis-bonus-salary</link>
      <description><p>Remuneration includes £3m bonus for turning round supermarket giant’s sales while finance chief earns £2.6m</p><p>Tesco boss Dave Lewis was paid £4.6m including a £3m bonus last year, when he stabilised the crisis-hit retailer and returned it to profit.</p><p>The UK’s largest supermarket group has experienced an upturn in sales amid the ongoing price war but the <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/apr/13/tesco-no-longer-in-crisis-chief-executive-profit-sales-share-price">outlook for profits remains gloomy</a>. Tesco made a pretax profit of £162m in the year to 27 February, after slumping £6.4bn into the red the year before – <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/apr/22/tesco-suffers-record-64bn-loss">the biggest loss ever recorded on the UK high street</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/13/tesco-boss-dave-lewis-bonus-salary">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>BBC may have shown bias against Corbyn, says former trust chair</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-bias-labour-sir-michael-lyons</link>
      <description><p>Sir Michael Lyons tells The World at One that he could understand people’s concerns about a loss of editorial impartiality</p><p>The BBC may have bowed to political pressure to show bias against Labour and Jeremy Corbyn, a former chair of the BBC Trust has said.</p><p>Sir Michael Lyons, who chaired the trust from 2007 to 2011 and is a former Labour councillor, claimed that there had been “some quite extraordinary attacks on the elected leader of the Labour party”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-bias-labour-sir-michael-lyons">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Prince Charles: I use homeopathy in animals to cut antibiotic use</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/prince-charles-use-homeopathy-in-animals-to-cut-antibiotic-use</link>
      <description><p>Homeopathy sceptic Dame Sally Davies among delegates to hear prince say he treats his cows with alternative medicine</p><p>Prince Charles has proposed a solution to the growing crisis of antibiotic over-use in animals and humans, telling an international gathering of scientists and government officials in London that he treats his own cows and sheep with homeopathy.</p><p>In front of the government’s chief medical officer, Dame Sally Davies, who once told a parliamentary committee that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/may/08/jeremy-hunt-homeopathy-studies-chief-medical-officer">homeopathy in humans was “rubbish”</a> and that she was “perpetually surprised that homeopathy is available on the NHS”, the prince explained to delegates from 20 nations and organisations why he had turned to homeopathic remedies for animals.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/prince-charles-use-homeopathy-in-animals-to-cut-antibiotic-use">Continue reading...</a></description>
