      <title>Super-rich may quit London homes under new anti-corruption rules</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/super-rich-may-sell-london-homes-under-anti-corruption-rules</link>
      <description><p>Estate agent predicts some billionaire clients will sell property if no longer able to keep identity secret via offshore firms<br></p><p>Super-rich international investors in London property are likely to sell off some of their mansions and penthouses after the introduction of anti-corruption rules cracking down on offshore secrecy, a leading estate agent has said.</p><p>Privacy-hungry oligarchs, media owners and tech billionaires from around the world could also abandon plans to buy homes in Britain because they would no longer be able to keep their identity secret by purchasing them through offshore companies, Trevor Abrahmsohn told the Guardian.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/super-rich-may-sell-london-homes-under-anti-corruption-rules">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Police watchdog to investigate Hillsborough inquest spin claims</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/police-watchdog-ipcc-investigate-hillsborough-inquest-spin-claims</link>
      <description><p>South Yorkshire police communications specialist says she was given ‘unethical’ instructions to try to influence coverage</p><p>The Independent Police Complaints Commission has launched an investigation into allegations that South Yorkshire police <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/05/south-yorkshire-police-tried-to-spin-evidence-at-hillsborough-inquests">tried to influence</a> daily media coverage of the Hillsborough inquests and spin what the force considered to be evidence favourable to it.</p><p>Hayley Court, a communications specialist hired by South Yorkshire police in 2014 specifically to work on the inquests, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/05/south-yorkshire-police-tried-to-spin-evidence-at-hillsborough-inquests">told the Guardian last week</a> that she believed she had been given “unethical” instructions to spin coverage for the force. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/police-watchdog-ipcc-investigate-hillsborough-inquest-spin-claims">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Number of suicides in England and Wales reaches 20-year high</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/number-of-suicides-in-england-and-wales-last-year-reaches-20-year-high</link>
      <description><p>Prince William meets mental health charity after figures show number of female suicides rose sharply in 2015</p><p>The number of women who killed themselves rose sharply last year as the total number of suicides for England and Wales reached a 20-year high. There were 3,899 rulings of suicide in coroners’ courts in 2015, according to figures released on Thursday by the Ministry of Justice – more than for any 12-month period since 1995, when the data series began. </p><p>While the number of men found to have killed themselves fell to 2,997, 23 fewer than in 2014, the number of women increased by 70 to 902. The fewest suicides were in 2007, when 3,007 such verdicts were recorded, and the number has risen consistently since then.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/number-of-suicides-in-england-and-wales-last-year-reaches-20-year-high">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>China may take over Hinkley Point nuclear project, claims Lord Howell</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/china-may-take-over-hinkley-point-nuclear-project-claims-lord-howell</link>
      <description><p>Suggestion comes as EDF faces more opposition from its own private shareholders to the Hinkley scheme at its annual general meeting in Paris </p><p>Chinese companies are ready to step in and offer to build new reactors at Hinkley Point in Somerset if French company EDF backs out of the government’s flagship energy project, it has been claimed.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>EDF <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/apr/24/hinkley-point-c-nuclear-power-plant-decision-delayed-again-by-edf">recently put back a final investment decision</a> until September amid mounting problems – not least whether it has the financial muscle to construct what may be the most expensive power plant ever.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/china-may-take-over-hinkley-point-nuclear-project-claims-lord-howell">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/director-general-fears-ministerial-influence-over-bbc-in-white-paper</link>
      <description><p>Director general Tony Hall expresses ‘honest disagreement’ over plans for government to appoint six members of executive board </p><p>Concerns that ministers will have too much power over the BBC, because they will be able to appoint six members of its executive board, were raised by the corporation’s director general <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-white-paper-key-points-john-whittingdale">after the publication of the white paper on its future</a>. </p><p>Tony Hall called the change in the BBC’s governance the “most significant reform in the BBC’s history” and said the broadcaster was still in dispute with the government over the implementation of plans. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/director-general-fears-ministerial-influence-over-bbc-in-white-paper">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Brexit could lead to recession, says Bank of England</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rates-on-hold-as-brexit-fears-bite</link>
      <description><p>Central bank issues unprecedented warning over EU vote, claiming exit could depress pound and raise unemployment<br></p><p>The Bank of England has warned for the first time that Britain could slide into recession in the aftermath of a vote to leave the EU in next month’s referendum.</p><p>Governor Mark Carney also warned Brexit could knock the pound sharply lower, stoke inflation and raise unemployment. That would leave the Bank with a difficult balancing act as it decides whether to cut, hold or raise interest rates to counter opposing forces, Carney added.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rates-on-hold-as-brexit-fears-bite">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/bankofenglandgovernor">Bank of England</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/business">Business</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/economics">Economics</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/interest-rates">Interest rates</category>

      <description><p>Daughter of schools minister Lord Nash is also helping draw up new curriculum for Future Academies – set up by Nash and his wife</p><p>An academy chain set up by the schools minister <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/education/2014/nov/11/academies-minister-lord-nash-breaching-governance-guidelines">Lord Nash</a> is allowing his unqualified and unpaid daughter to teach history and help draw up a new curriculum, prompting concerns from parents and a teachers’ union.</p><p><a href="http://www.futureacademies.org/">Future Academies</a> in Pimlico, central London, was set up by the minister in charge of academies and his wife, Caroline.       <title>Libor rigging defendant says he was beaten and humiliated at work</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/libor-rigging-defendant-says-beaten-humiliated-work-barclays</link>
      <description><p>Barclays trader tells trial that he was given no training and was hit with mini baseball bat and often mocked, and didn’t realise rate changes were illegal </p><p>A Barclays trader accused of conspiring to fix the Libor benchmark lending rate was humiliated and “whacked” across the back of the head with a baseball bat when he made mistakes at work, a court has heard.</p><p>Jonathan Mathew started working at the bank when he was just 19, not having been to university or having had any formal training. The 35-year-old told Southwark crown court how a senior trader, Peter Johnson, was a “hard taskmaster” and would berate him in the office when he got things wrong.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/libor-rigging-defendant-says-beaten-humiliated-work-barclays">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Up to 1,000 homes in Bath evacuated over suspected unexploded bomb</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/up-to-1000-homes-in-bath-evacuated-over-suspected-unexploded-bomb</link>
      <description><p>Device, believed to date from second world war, found during excavation work at a school</p><p>As many as 1,000 homes are being evacuated after a suspected unexploded second world war device was found at a school. A 300-metre exclusion zone has been set up following the discovery at Lansdown Road in Bath, where contractors using a digger unearthed the device at the Royal High School.</p><p>People living nearby are being evacuated to Bath racecourse, and motorists are being asked to find alternative routes, as some roads in the area have been closed.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/up-to-1000-homes-in-bath-evacuated-over-suspected-unexploded-bomb">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Ex-Deutsche Bank executive given four-and-a-half years for insider trading</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/ex-deutsche-bank-boss-martyn-dodgson-four-and-a-half-years-for-insider-trading</link>
      <description><p>Martyn Dodgson and ex-finance director Andrew Hind jailed for making deals on stock markets using classified information </p><p>A former Deutsche Bank managing director and an accountant have been sent to prison for “persistent, prolonged, deliberate, dishonest behaviour”, drawing a line under the UK financial watchdog’s eight-and-a-half year insider dealing inquiry.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/painstaking-investigation-deutsche-bank-insider-trading">Martyn Dodgson</a>, a 44-year-old financier who advised the government during the financial crisis, was sentenced to four-and-a-half years on Thursday for his part in an elaborate scam that prosecutors said made more than £6.9m between 2006 and 2010. It is the longest UK prison term handed down for the crime. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/ex-deutsche-bank-boss-martyn-dodgson-four-and-a-half-years-for-insider-trading">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/nhs-whistleblower-treated-unfairly-alleging-death-rate-fixing-wolverhampton</link>
      <description><p>Review finds Royal Wolverhampton NHS Trust was not fair to Sandra Haynes-Kirkbright after she alleged coding flaws</p><p>An NHS whistleblower who claimed she was treated badly by a hospital trust after alleging it had been fixing its death rates was treated unfairly, a report has found.<br></p><p>Sandra Haynes-Kirkbright was head of clinical coding at the Royal Wolverhampton NHS Trust when she first alleged there were systematic flaws in its data leading to overpayments to the hospital trust.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/nhs-whistleblower-treated-unfairly-alleging-death-rate-fixing-wolverhampton">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Met Office predicts cooler weekend following fine weather</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/met-office-predicts-cooler-weekend-following-fine-weather</link>
      <description><p>After the hottest day of the year last weekend, 27.1C in parts of London, forecasters are predicting a drop in fortunes</p><p>Last Sunday might have been the hottest day of the year so far in some parts of the UK – but don’t expect a second weekend of barbecue summer weather. That’s the warning from forecasters <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/08/britain-hotter-than-ibiza-during-exceptional-may-heatwave">following a week of fine and warm conditions</a> for much of the British Isles.</p><p>The fine spell is set to come to an end as winds turn increasingly northerly and bring much chillier air down from the north across the UK. As a result, temperatures are set to drop sharply and this weekend will be much cooler than last when Northolt in west London managed 27.1C (80F) on Sunday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/met-office-predicts-cooler-weekend-following-fine-weather">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>British man accused of killing his family caught at California homeless camp</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/briton-accused-killing-family-arrested-california-homeless-camp</link>
      <description><p>Police say Dave McCann fled after killing his estranged wife and her mother and was discovered in a remote location based on a tip from a homeless person</p><p>A British man on the run after allegedly killing his wife and mother-in-law in California was found sleeping at a homeless encampment on the coast Wednesday, ending a four-day search for the homicide suspect.</p><p>Police in Clovis, a city three hours south-east of San Francisco, said Dave McCann, 47, fled on Saturday after killing his <a href="http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-clovis-murder-suspect-arrested-20160511-story.html">estranged</a> wife Tierney Cooper-McCann, 36, and her mother Judith Cooper, 68, and was discovered in a remote location in the middle of the night based on a tip from a homeless person.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/briton-accused-killing-family-arrested-california-homeless-camp">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Birmingham pub bombings coroner has 'significant' new information</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/birmingham-pub-bombings-ira-coroner-sent-significant-information</link>
      <description><p>Undisclosed source sent material relating to claims that police had advanced warnings of the IRA attacks to coroner</p><p>A “significant” piece of information relating to advance warning about the IRA’s Birmingham pub bombings has been sent to the coroner who is considering whether to reopen the inquest into the 1974 atrocity.<br></p><p>Louise Hunt, the senior coroner for Birmingham and Solihull, told a hearing on Thursday that the new material had been sent to her office on 27 April from an undisclosed source.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/birmingham-pub-bombings-ira-coroner-sent-significant-information">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/uk/ira">IRA</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/uk/uksecurity">UK security and counter-terrorism</category>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 14:05:59 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/birmingham-pub-bombings-ira-coroner-sent-significant-information</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/c05d038095f19b2a0d1acbd0c5ac09ec19dc7181/0_0_4781_2869/4781.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=6e6fbb53cd612a600de9c1c1a45dcbb7">

      <title>Appeal for information after woman in her 70s raped in London</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/appeal-for-information-after-man-raped-woman-in-her-70s-in-london</link>
      <description><p>Woman was attacked on Wednesday morning after the man forced his way into her house</p><p> Police are hunting a man who forced his way into the home of a woman in her 7os before beating and raping her. The attack happened in Purley, south-east London on Wednesday at around 7.50am.</p><p>The victim has given detectives specific details of her attacker that may help in his capture. The woman believes he had a tattoo or a mark on his neck, and a tattoo on the left side of his chest, which she has described as circular. Police have added that the attacker was white, may have spoken with a Scottish accent, and appeared to be aged between 40 and 50 years old.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/appeal-for-information-after-man-raped-woman-in-her-70s-in-london">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Children's services call for funds to deal with rise in child refugees</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/childrens-services-call-for-resources-to-deal-with-rise-in-child-refugees</link>
      <description><p>UK council leaders welcome government decision to take in more lone refugee children but say they need extra resources</p><p>Council leaders, children’s services and foster carer networks have called on the government to properly resource local authorities to cope with the expected rise in unaccompanied child asylum seekers entering Britain.<br></p><p>They have warned that existing funding is inadequate to meet the needs of often traumatised children fleeing conflict zones and have voiced concerns over the government’s failure so far to provide details of how children arriving alone will be assessed and transferred to different parts of the country.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/childrens-services-call-for-resources-to-deal-with-rise-in-child-refugees">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Families destroyed by Mao’s political upheaval say they cannot forgive while China still refuses to face up to its past</p><p>Chen Shuxiang shakes his head when asked if he can forgive the teenagers who chained his father to a radiator and used an iron bar to bludgeon him to death.</p><p>It was the summer of 1966 when Chen Yanrong became one of the first victims of Chairman Mao’s Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, a cataclysmic political upheaval that started 50 years ago this month.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/victims-cultural-revolution-50-years-china-mao">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Mohammed bin Salman: the prince trying to wean Saudi Arabia off oil</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/mohammed-bin-salman-the-prince-trying-to-ween-saudi-arabia-off-oil</link>
      <description><p>King Salman’s favourite son is modernising the Arab world’s largest economy but some fear his big plan could fail to materialise</p><p>Hardly a week has gone by recently without dramatic headlines about Saudi Arabia planning far-reaching changes. And every report features the intriguing character of Mohammed bin Salman, the deputy crown prince and rising star of an increasingly unpredictable kingdom.</p><p>Bin Salman, an imposing man of 30, oversees a team of advisers and ministers who are working on the grandiosely named<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/25/saudi-arabia-approves-ambitious-plan-to-move-economy-beyond-oil"> Vision 2030 </a>– designed to prepare pampered Saudis for a life after oil by diversifying, privatising and modernising the largest economy in the Arab world.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/mohammed-bin-salman-the-prince-trying-to-ween-saudi-arabia-off-oil">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Zika virus makes Rio Olympics a threat in Brazil and abroad, health expert says</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/rio-olympics-zika-amir-attaran-public-health-threat</link>
      <description><p>Amir Attaran calls for postponement or moving of Games and says biggest risk is spreading the virus to countries without adequate healthcare infrastructure </p><p>As Brazil reels from a spiraling political crisis and its deepest recession in decades, a public health specialist in Canada has added to the country’s woes with a high-profile call for the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/olympic-games-2016">2016 summer Olympics</a> – slated to kick off in Rio de Janeiro in early August – to be postponed or moved due to the Zika outbreak.<br></p><p>“But for the Games, would anyone recommend sending an extra half a million visitors into Brazil right now?” Canadian professor Amir Attaran, whose research areas include population health and global development policy, asked this week in a commentary <a href="http://harvardpublichealthreview.org/off-the-podium-why-rios-2016-olympic-games-must-not-proceed/#_edn5">published in the Harvard Public Health Review</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/rio-olympics-zika-amir-attaran-public-health-threat">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>German growth more than doubles - business live</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2016/may/13/german-growth-more-than-doubles-business-live</link>
      <description><p>The German economy grew by 0.7% in first quarter, beating expectations and outpacing growth of 0.3% in the previous quarter</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T07:26:42.019Z">8.26am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Will there be any horror stories for markets on Friday 13th?</strong></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T07:04:59.206Z">8.04am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Carsten Brzeski, economist at ING, describes Germany’s economic performance over recent months as “very impressive”.</strong></p><p>Brzeski believes the makeup of Europe’s largest economy is changing. Is Germany losing its industrial might?</p><p>During this lucky streak, the growth drivers have changed. Initially boosted by strong industrial production and exports, the economy is currently much more driven by private consumption, construction and a bit of exports. </p><p>The industrial backbone has weakened significantly. Looking ahead, at least in the near term, this new growth mix should further support growth. <br></p><p>Today’s data are another sign of Germany’s economic strength. At least at first glance. The economy defied the financial market turmoil at the start of the year as well as the Chinese slowdown. </p><p>Even if many Germans don’t want to hear it, strong domestic activity is also the result of the ECB’s loose monetary policy. At second glance, however, the strong growth performance also shows what currently is the biggest risk for the German economy: complacency.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2016/may/13/german-growth-more-than-doubles-business-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 07:28:24 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2016/may/13/german-growth-more-than-doubles-business-live</guid>

      <title>Apple invests $1bn in Didi Chuxing, China's Uber rival</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/apple-didi-chuxing-china-uber-rival</link>
      <description><p>Tim Cook says investment – single largest ever in Chinese ride-hailing service – allows Apple to learn more about the market there </p><p>Apple has invested $1bn in Didi Chuxing, China’s version of Uber, CEO Tim Cook said on Thursday.</p><p>Ahead of a high-profile visit to the country later in May, Cook told <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/us-apple-china-idUSKCN0Y404W">Reuters</a> that the investment would create opportunities to partner with Didi – fuelling speculation that Apple is making a strategic investment that complements its own plans for a new electric car.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/apple-didi-chuxing-china-uber-rival">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Refugees urge Kenyan leaders to rethink closure of Dadaab camp</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/13/refugees-urge-kenyan-leaders-to-rethink-closure-of-dadaab-camp</link>
      <description><p>Residents in world’s biggest refugee camp, some of whom have lived there for decades, tell of their sadness at decision</p><p> Residents of the world’s biggest refugee camp have called on the Kenyan government to reverse plans to close the settlement, saying proposals for forced returns of Somalis to their war-torn country would amount to a mass death sentence.<br></p><p>Abdullahi Aden Hassan, a father of nine who was one of the first to arrive in the Dadaab camp fleeing the civil war in Somalia in 1992, told the Guardian refugees had received the news, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/kenya-close-worlds-biggest-refugee-camp-dadaab">confirmed this week</a>, with shock.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/13/refugees-urge-kenyan-leaders-to-rethink-closure-of-dadaab-camp">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Some US states fall short on tax transparency, says Cameron</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/tax-transparency-efforts-fail-american-states-excluded-summit</link>
      <description><p>Prime minister casts doubt on whether United States can be part of ‘coalition of the committed’ against corruption</p><p>David Cameron has cast doubt on whether the United States could be truly considered part of a coalition committed to the fight against corruption, saying some US states fall far short on tax transparency and are less open than the UK’s crown dependencies.</p><p>The prime minister made his remarks at the close of a corruption summit in London that brought together more than 40 countries, including the US, in an attempt to fight corruption, restore stolen assets and toughen laws to fight evasion.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/tax-transparency-efforts-fail-american-states-excluded-summit">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Australian security guard killed in shooting at embassy in Baghdad</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/shooting-at-australian-embassy-in-baghdad-leaves-security-contractor-dead-reports</link>
      <description><p>Department of Foreign Affairs recently dismissed claims diplomats at the embassy in the Iraqi capital had been put at risk by cuts to security</p><p> An Australian security contractor has been shot dead at the country’s embassy in Baghdad, the Department of Foreign Affairs has confirmed.</p><p>The 34-year-old man, who has not been named, was an employee of Unity Resources Group, which provides security to the embassy.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/shooting-at-australian-embassy-in-baghdad-leaves-security-contractor-dead-reports">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Trump and Ryan: meeting was a 'very positive step' toward GOP unity – as it happened</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2016/may/12/us-election-live-trump-paul-ryan-meeting</link>
      <description><ul><li>Presumptive nominee and congressional leaders meet on Capitol Hill</li><li>‘I want to be part of the unifying process,’ House speaker has said</li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/moderate-republicans-donald-trump-hillary-clinton">Take it or leave it: Trump’s rise puts GOP moderates in tough corner</a></li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/911-commission-saudi-arabia-hijackers">Saudi officials were supporting 9/11 hijackers, commission member says</a></li></ul><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T02:25:12.656Z">3.25am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Can’t we all just get along?</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T02:11:35.565Z">3.11am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has announced that he plans to “invit[e] leading conservatives and people from across the political spectrum” to talk with him about accusations of political bias at the social media company.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk">Zuckerberg invites top conservatives to talk and denies Facebook bias</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2016/may/12/us-election-live-trump-paul-ryan-meeting">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Walkout at Ugandan president's inauguration over ICC remarks</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/walkout-at-ugandan-presidents-inauguration-over-icc-remarks</link>
      <description><p>US, Canadian and European diplomats protest after Yoweri Museveni says international criminal court is ‘a bunch of useless people’</p><p>Delegates from North America and Europe who were attending t<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/uganda-president-yoweri-museveni-sworn-in-fifth-term">he inauguration of the Ugandan president, Yoweri Museveni</a>, have walked out of the ceremony in protest against his comments about the international criminal court (ICC) in The Hague, and the presence of Sudan’s leader, whom the court has indicted.</p><p>Elizabeth Trudeau, a spokeswoman for the US state department, said the US ambassador to Uganda, Deborah Malac, and a visiting Washington-based official, along with several European and Canadian diplomats, abruptly left the inauguration on Thursday after Museveni made negative remarks about the ICC in his inaugural address. She said that the US also objected to the participation in the inauguration of the Sudanese president, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/15/south-africa-to-fight-omar-al-bashirs-arrest-warrant-sudan">Omar al-Bashir</a>. Bashir has been charged by the court for atrocities in Sudan’s western region Darfur.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/walkout-at-ugandan-presidents-inauguration-over-icc-remarks">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Egypt's activists turn to social media to call for satirists' release</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/egypts-activists-social-media-facebook-satirists-release-awlad-el-shawarea</link>
      <description><p>Clips uploaded to Facebook featured activists demanding the release of members of group Awlad el-Shawarea</p><p>Egyptian activists are using social media to demand the release of five detained members of a satirical street performance group whose video clips mocked the president, Abdel Fatah al-Sisi.</p><p>The activists posted pictures on Facebook of themselves holding mobile phones in front of their faces with the caption: “Does a mobile phone camera rattle you?”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/egypts-activists-social-media-facebook-satirists-release-awlad-el-shawarea">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Red Cross aid convoy denied entry to Syrian city of Darayya</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/red-cross-convoy-denied-entery-to-syrian-city-of-darayya</link>
      <description><p>Five-truck convoy was not allowed to deliver nutrition items for children and vaccines to besieged city</p><p>An aid convoy has been refused entry to the besieged Syrian city of Darayya , the Red Cross said, dashing hopes for the first such delivery since regime forces surrounded the rebel-held town in 2012.</p><p>Meanwhile, a truce in Aleppo has expired with no new last-minute prolongation after it had been extended twice through last-minute intervention by Moscow and Washington. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/red-cross-convoy-denied-entery-to-syrian-city-of-darayya">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Beer hall where Hitler spoke ordered to host anti-immigrant party event</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/court-orders-german-beer-hall-to-host-anti-immigrant-party-event</link>
      <description><p>Owner of hall where Hitler is thought to have made his first political speech had cancelled event over security concerns</p><p>A Munich court has ordered the owner of a beer hall where Adolf Hitler is thought to have made his first political speech to allow the anti-immigrant party Alternative for Germany (AfD) to hold an event there. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/01/german-far-right-party-ban-minarets-burqa-alternative-fur-deutschland">German far-right party calls for ban on minarets and burqa</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/court-orders-german-beer-hall-to-host-anti-immigrant-party-event">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/germany">Germany</category>

    <item>
      <title>Secret area of Guantánamo could be opened to UN watchdog for first time</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/guantanamo-camp-7-torture-ammar-al-baluchi-un</link>
      <description><p><strong>Exclusive:</strong> Attorneys for alleged 9/11 co-conspirator request UN access to Camp 7 to prevent evidence they say was coerced during torture being used against him</p><p>The most secret corner of Guantánamo Bay could be opened up to the UN torture watchdog for the first time, if an audacious legal gambit succeeds.</p><p>Attorneys for Ammar al-Baluchi, one of the accused 9/11 co-conspirators facing a military tribunal at Guantánamo Bay, will request on Thursday that the judge in the case order access to Guantánamo’s Camp 7 – where he and other detainees formerly in brutal CIA custody reside practically incommunicado – for Juan Mendez, the UN’s special rapporteur on torture.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/guantanamo-camp-7-torture-ammar-al-baluchi-un">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>George Zimmerman's gun used to kill Trayvon Martin back up for auction</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/george-zimmerman-gun-trayvon-martin-gun-auction-website-removed</link>
      <description><p>Handgun, which Zimmerman calls a ‘piece of American history’, reappears on firearms site after it was pulled from GunBroker.com amid widespread criticism</p><p>An attempt by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/george-zimmerman">George Zimmerman</a> to auction the gun he used to kill Trayvon Martin in 2012 appeared to be back on again Thursday following an extraordinary day in which the owner of the first website on which the weapon first appeared took down the listing, saying he wanted no part of the controversial sale.</p><p>Billed as “your opportunity to own a piece of American history”, Zimmerman’s listing abruptly disappeared from GunBroker.com shortly after the auction’s advertised 11am ET start time. The former neighbourhood watch volunteer, who was acquitted three years ago over the death of the unarmed black teenager in Sanford, Florida – a case that sparked protests and a national debate about race relations – was seeking at least $5,000 for the gun.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/george-zimmerman-gun-trayvon-martin-gun-auction-website-removed">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Italian court orders release of man held in Bari terror inquiry</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/italian-court-orders-release-hakim-nasiri-bari-terror-inquiry</link>
      <description><p>Lawyer for Hakim Nasiri says his client is innocent, while two other men arrested in connection with case remain in custody</p><p>An Italian judge has ordered the release of a terror suspect who was alleged to have scoped targets in the UK and Italy and whose arrest was hailed as a sign of Italy’s effective counter-terrorism programme.</p><p>The decision to release Hakim Nasiri, a 23-year-old Afghan, was not formally explained by the presiding judge, Francesco Agnino. The court ruled that two other suspects who were arrested this week in connection with the same alleged terror ring on suspicion of aiding illegal immigration should remain in custody.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/italian-court-orders-release-hakim-nasiri-bari-terror-inquiry">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/egypt-hidden-chambers-tutankhamun-tomb-nefertiti</link>
      <description><p>Scientists accuse government of failing to release data disproving claims that burial site contains Nefertiti’s remains</p><p>The world of archaeology was electrified last year by the news that Tutankhamun’s tomb could contain hidden chambers possibly containing the remains and riches of Queen Nefertiti. Experts hope new chambers could contain tomb of Nefertiti</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/egypt-hidden-chambers-tutankhamun-tomb-nefertiti">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/indian-doctors-ivf-woman-70s-gives-birth-fertility-treatment-daljinder-kaur</link>
      <description><p>Doctors call for upper age limit for fertility treatment after Daljinder Kaur has first child after 46 years of marriage</p><p>Doctors in India have raised concerns about IVF treatment in the country, after a couple in their 70s had their first child after 46 years of marriage. Daljinder Kaur, who does not have a birth certificate but is thought be in her 70s, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/indian-woman-in-her-70s-gives-birth-to-healthy-baby-boy">gave birth to a boy</a> last month after two years of fertility treatment using donor eggs at a clinic in the northern state of Haryana.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/10/foul-reign-of-the-biological-clock">The foul reign of the biological clock | Moira Weigel</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/indian-doctors-ivf-woman-70s-gives-birth-fertility-treatment-daljinder-kaur">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>US and UK urge banks to do business with Iran</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/us-and-uk-urge-banks-to-do-business-with-iran</link>
      <description><p>Iranian president Hassan Rouhani is under pressure from hardliners as lifting of sanctions fails to live up to expectations</p><p>An attempt by the US and UK governments to persuade European banks to do more business in Iran in the wake of last year’s nuclear deal, appears to have fallen on deaf ears.</p><p>Senior representatives from nine major banks listened on Thursday to appeals from the US secretary of state, John Kerry, and the British foreign secretary, Philip Hammond, urging them to help finance expanded trade with Iran following the lifting of sanctions under the agreement sealed in Vienna last July. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/us-and-uk-urge-banks-to-do-business-with-iran">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>South African musicians hail end of 'cultural imperialism' on radio</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/south-african-musicians-hail-end-of-cultural-imperialism-with-radio-quota</link>
      <description><p>National broadcaster SABC announces that 90% of music played on its 18 radio stations will be from local artists</p><p>South African musicians have joyfully welcomed an announcement that their music will dominate the country’s airwaves after years of “cultural imperialism”.<br></p><p>The national broadcaster, <a href="http://www.sabc.co.za/wps/portal/SABC/SABCHOME">SABC</a>, decided this week that 90% of the music played on its radio stations would be by local artists, a move that one of South Africa’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/dec/25/the-playlist-the-best-south-african-hip-hop-of-2014-with-tumi-and-aka">hip-hop</a> stars compared to Nelson Mandela’s release from prison.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/south-african-musicians-hail-end-of-cultural-imperialism-with-radio-quota">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Queen wins £50 Tesco gift card at horse show</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/queen-wins-tesco-gift-card-at-the-races-royal-windsor-horse-show</link>
      <description><p>Prize at Royal Windsor equestrian event delights the monarch – but Tesco is not among suppliers with royal warrants</p><p>Every little helps when your food shop rings up at an <a draggable="true" href="https://www.royal.uk/sites/default/files/media/sovereign_grant_annual_report_2014-15.pdf">average £25,000</a> a week. So the Queen was understandably delighted when she won a £50 Tesco gift card at an equestrian event.</p><p>The monarch grinned as she clutched the credit card-sized voucher at the Royal Windsor horse show. Her horse Barber’s Shop won the Tattersalls &amp; RoR Thoroughbred Ridden Show. However, it is unlikely that she ever eats anything from Tesco, since the company does not appear on the list of firms with royal warrants.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/queen-wins-tesco-gift-card-at-the-races-royal-windsor-horse-show">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Billions review: I feel naughty – guilty even – for enjoying it</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/13/billions-review-naughty-guilty-damian-lewis</link>
      <description><p>You won’t learn much about Wall Street post 9/11 – it’s just macho men Damian Lewis and Paul Giamatti going head to head. Hell it’s fun, though</p><p>Have you lost a bit of self-belief, confidence at work perhaps? Let’s hope you watched new US import <a href="https://www.sky.com/watch/channel/sky-atlantic/billions" title=""><strong>Billions</strong></a> (Sky Atlantic) then. I did, and I picked up a few things. So if anyone reading this online is maybe thinking of leaving a nasty comment below the line (it’s a subject <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/12/the-dark-side-of-guardian-comments" title="">close to the Guardian’s heart</a> at the moment), you know what, I’m not even listening. Or reading. No sir, I’m listening to the voice inside telling me where the alpha is. It’s the voice that got me here, and it’s still there. What’s it saying? That I’m awesome. (I’m now standing up and beating my chest with my fist, awesomely). And to anyone who says that I’m not, do you know what it’s saying? “Fuck you”, that’s what it’s saying.</p><p>That’s the advice psychiatrist Wendy Rhoades (Maggie Siff) gives a guy whose mojo – and results – are a little down at the hedge fund where she works as performance coach. (Must have a word with the boss here about getting one of them, hopefully exactly like Wendy, who is seriously impressive.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/13/billions-review-naughty-guilty-damian-lewis">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Dandruff? Soon you'll be reaching for the scalp yoghurt</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/12/scalp-bacteria-could-be-key-to-keeping-dandruff-flakes-at-bay-propionibacterium</link>
      <description><p>Study into the ecosystem of microbes on scalps suggests that nurturing a type of bacteria, called Propionibacterium, could help prevent dandruff</p><p>The next time dandruff dots your shoulders, you might want to reach for yogurt, not shampoo. The latest study into scaly scalps has found that nurturing particular bacteria on the skin could keep the white flakes at bay.</p><p>Researchers in Shanghai took on the dandruff problem with an unprecedented investigation into flaky scalps and the ecosystem of microbes that set up home on the human head, feeding on the lavish menu of dead skin and oily secretions called sebum.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/may/12/scalp-bacteria-could-be-key-to-keeping-dandruff-flakes-at-bay-propionibacterium">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Shrill: Notes from a Loud Woman by Lindy West – ‘I never wanted internet trolls to be my beat’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/13/shrill-notes-from-a-loud-woman-lindy-west-review</link>
      <description><p>West’s memoir is full of a wild, joyous vulgarity and ranges from body images and rape threats to puberty and her love for her husband</p><p>In 2013, Lindy West got a message on Twitter from her dead father. “Embarrassed father of an idiot,” his bio said. But no: “My dad was never mean. It couldn’t really be&nbsp;from him. Also, he was dead – just 18 months earlier, I’d&nbsp;watched him turn grey and drown in his own magnificent lungs.” Someone wanted to hurt her.</p><p>At that moment in her career, West was fielding daily online harassment for her opposition to rape jokes in standup comedy. “I was eating 30 rape threats for breakfast at that point (or, more accurately, ‘You’re fatter than the girls I usually rape’ threats),” she writes in this memoir. “No one could touch me any more.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/13/shrill-notes-from-a-loud-woman-lindy-west-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 10 budget cafes and restaurants in Belfast</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/13/top-10-budget-restaurants-cafes-belfast-northern-ireland</link>
      <description><p>Belfast is bursting with options for good, affordable food – from fish and chips and Tex-Mex to southern Indian and modern British. Updating <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2011/jul/07/belfast-budget-restaurants">our 2011 guide</a>, here are great places to eat for under £10 a head</p><p>Belfast foodies talk about Boojum with almost mystical reverence. That might seem OTT for what, at first glance, looks like a standard Tex-Mex, assembly-line burrito joint, but Boojum is a cut above that. The thick and tender, rope-like tangle of braised, shredded beef in my fat fist of a burrito was excellent. Like everything else in that wrap – from a stridently hot, smoky salsa to the spicy, tomato-based savoury rice – it had a fresh, well-defined flavour. No wonder Boojum is busy.<br><strong>Note: it also has a branch at Botanic Avenue</strong><br>• <em>Dishes from £5.10. 19-27 Chichester Street, 028-9023 0600, </em><a href="http://www.boojummex.com/"><em>boojummex.com</em></a><em>. Open daily 11.30am-10pm</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/13/top-10-budget-restaurants-cafes-belfast-northern-ireland">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The false widow spider and the woodlouse</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/13/country-diary-false-widow-spider-woodlouse</link>
      <description><p><strong>Havant, Hampshire</strong> As I watched, a woodlouse blundered into a translucent tripline and the web vibrated</p><p>My gardening gloves had lain abandoned in the shed for several months as the cold, wet spring had thwarted any plans to plant out early crops. When I went to put them on they pulled away from the rough-planked shed wall with a sound like ripping Velcro. As I peeled off a candyfloss puff of cobweb, a rotund spider the size of my fingernail scuttled across the back of my hand and dropped to the floor.</p><p>A neighbour sauntered over after hearing me yelp. “Kill it,” he advised as we watched the arachnid squeeze into a crack in the wood behind its three-dimensional web. “That’s one of those venomous foreign spiders. They’re dangerous, I’ve seen the news …”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/13/country-diary-false-widow-spider-woodlouse">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>US poultry workers wear diapers on job over lack of bathroom breaks – report</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/poultry-workers-wear-diapers-work-bathroom-breaks</link>
      <description><ul><li>Oxfam says many are afraid to ask for permission to go to the bathroom<br></li><li>One supplier calls allegations ‘troubling’ and refusal of breaks not tolerated<br></li></ul><p>A <a href="https://www.oxfamamerica.org/static/media/files/No_Relief_Embargo.pdf">report</a> from international advocacy group Oxfam says poultry workers in the United States labor in a “climate of fear”, with some forced to wear diapers on the job. </p><p> It says many workers are afraid to ask for permission to go to the bathroom. The report says a worker at a Simmons Foods plant in Arkansas told Oxfam that she and many others resorted to wearing diapers. A Tyson Foods worker says in the report that many workers at his North Carolina plant “have to urinate in their pants”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/poultry-workers-wear-diapers-work-bathroom-breaks">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-news">US news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/oxfam">Oxfam</category>

    <item>
      <title>Jessy Lanza: Oh No review – wonky pop, peak danceability</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/jessy-lanza-oh-no-review-wonky-pop-peak-danceability</link>
      <description><p>(Hyperdub)</p><p>When Canada’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/24/jessy-lanza-r-and-b-singer">Jessy Lanza</a> debuted with 2013’s Pull My Hair Back, she was <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/aug/15/timbaland-future-stars-experimental-cassie">pigeonholed</a> as one of the “future R&amp;B” artists mixing up 90s sounds with new electronics. Understandably, she and co-producer/husband Jeremy Greenspan have made a run for it on second album Oh No and a wider – and weirder – range of influences, from <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2004/jan/09/popandrock.shopping1">Yellow Magic Orchestra </a>and J-pop to Chicago footwork and New Orleans bounce, shine through their wonky pop prism. Lanza’s smoky sensuality is still there on slow jams such as Begins, Could Be You and I Talk BB, which recalls one of Prince’s syrupiest piano moments. But much of it is, brilliantly, like something from a dusty Dance Mania tape, recognisable only by Lanza’s distinct, vapour-light voice. At times, the production can be overly fussy (see Going Somewhere), but tracks such as VV Violence (squelchy electro-funk by way of girlish electroclash) and Never Enough (a nod to smooth house dude <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/oct/26/dj-morgan-geist-favourite-tracks">Morgan Geist</a>) demonstrate their ability to team that experimentalism with peak-time danceability. There could be a bona fide pop star in Jessy Lanza yet.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/jessy-lanza-oh-no-review-wonky-pop-peak-danceability">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Welcome, Lord Prime Minister: Cambodian media told to use leader's full royal title</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/cambodian-media-prime-minister-hun-sen-full-royal-title</link>
      <description><p>Print, radio and TV organisations told to use Hun Sen’s honorary six-word title in opening lines of all stories about him or face legal action</p><p>For years, some Cambodian media have referred to the country’s longtime leader as Prime Minister Hun Sen – but, as of Thursday, authorities have warned that this must stop.<br></p><p>Starting in August, all media must use his full, honorary, six-word title – “Samdech Akka Moha Sena Padei Techo Hun Sen” – in the opening lines of print articles, radio and TV stories about him. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/cambodian-media-prime-minister-hun-sen-full-royal-title">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Whily Tommy’s in London, his family stoke up another turf war; and the artist examines the gender conflict behind antisocial behaviour.     <item>
      <title>Why I wish I hadn't learned how to make pizza</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/why-i-wish-i-hadnt-learned-how-to-make-pizza</link>
      <description><p>Who knew that making your own pizza is actually cheaper and quicker than takeaway? Well Delia, obviously</p><ul><li>Don’t miss the double-sized Italian issue of Guardian Cook this weekend<br></li></ul><p>Unlike Delia, I have very few iron rules, but here’s one: you should never find out how the magic trick works. It’s not exciting if you know the lady hasn’t really been sawn in half or that the rabbit was in the magician’s sleeve all along. As long as you don’t know it’s all a trick, every wardrobe might, conceivably, have an enchanted kingdom at the back of it.</p><p>All of this is a convoluted way of saying: I really wish I hadn’t learned how to make pizza.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/why-i-wish-i-hadnt-learned-how-to-make-pizza">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/12/is-the-new-non-sweat-cycle-shirt-for-commuters-worth-it</link>
      <description><p>A shirt that promises to stop you sweating – or stinking – has gone on sale for £139. We asked an editor to try it out for size</p><p>Many offices now have shower facilities for cyclists, and those that don’t at least have toilet cubicles for commuters to change out of their kit. But if you’ve not got the time, or can’t be bothered carrying a spare set of clothes, or use your bike to get between meetings during the day, then a shirt that stops you sweating – and stinking out the joint – could be a thing of joy and wonder. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/12/is-the-new-non-sweat-cycle-shirt-for-commuters-worth-it">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Selfie entitlement: why theatre's meet-and-greet crowd are missing the point</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/stage/theatreblog/2016/may/12/theatre-kit-harington-dr-faustus</link>
      <description><p>Some audience members seem to think their ticket guarantees an autograph too, but actors are well within their rights to miss the late-evening salutations</p><p>When the Duke of York’s theatre <a href="https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2016/more-floods-at-duke-of-yorks-theatre-cancel-doctor-faustus-performances/">flooded last month</a>, necessitating the cancellation of the matinee and evening performances of Doctor Faustus, Kit Harington pitched up in the foyer to greet disappointed theatregoers and sign posters as refunds and exchanges were sorted.</p><p>It was a nice touch and a recognition that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/theatreblog/2016/may/02/kit-harington-faustus-west-end-jamie-lloyd">Harington’s star status</a> is a significant factor in attracting audiences to Jamie Lloyd’s staging of Marlowe’s damnation drama. But on Broadway recently, another British performer – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/jul/27/cynthia-erivo-the-color-purple-broadway-production">the wonderful Cynthia Erivo</a>, who has just <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/may/03/tony-awards-hamilton-musical-makes-history-with-16-nominations">received a Tony nomination</a> for her performance in the musical The Color Purple – found herself being damned on Twitter. One theatregoer was outraged that after the evening performance, on a day when Erivo had already done a matinee, the actor didn’t sign autographs and pose for pictures with all those waiting after the show.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/stage/theatreblog/2016/may/12/theatre-kit-harington-dr-faustus">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>JK Rowling handwrites quote for fan's tattoo</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/12/jk-rowling-handwrites-quote-for-fans-tattoo-harry-potter</link>
      <description><p>Author obliges after Harry Potter devotee appeals in tweet for author to write ‘expecto patronum’</p><p>A Harry Potter fan who asked author JK Rowling for a special favour to help her stop self-harming was rewarded yesterday with a personal response from the author.</p><p>Twitter user Kate <a href="https://twitter.com/AlwaysJLover/status/730426312490389506">explained in a message</a> to Rowling how she had been through “so many things in my life, from sexual assault to bullying to attempted suicide eight times”, and that she was “also trying my hardest to stop self-harming”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/12/jk-rowling-handwrites-quote-for-fans-tattoo-harry-potter">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/books/jkrowling">JK Rowling</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/books/books">Books</category>

    <item>
      <title>Money Monster review - George Clooney goes Leslie Nielsen in popcorn hostage thriller</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/money-monster-review-george-clooney-jodie-foster-cannes-2016</link>
      <description><p>The Jodie Foster-directed satire about the financial meltdown isn’t especially original, but it’s arguably more honest than Oscar favourite The Big Short</p><p>A miasma of pure silliness settles on this movie directed by Jodie Foster, showing here in Cannes out of competition; it deserves a genre of its own: screwball action. Julia Roberts plays a harassed TV producer who has to keep in line her waning star: Lee Gates, played by George Clooney, the ego-crazed, silver-fox presenter of a TV show called Money Monster, giving stock picks and spurious shock-jock-type commentary on the market, celebrating unfettered capitalism by breaking into embarrassingly geriatric hip-hop moves with backing dancers. (He reportedly bears a certain resemblance to a real-life pundit: Jim Cramer, presenter of a programme called Mad Money, on CNBC.) </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/money-monster-review-george-clooney-jodie-foster-cannes-2016">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How It Works: The Dad review – are the Ladybird spoof books funny or anti-funny?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/12/ladybird-the-dad-review-zoe-williams</link>
      <description><p>The hugely successful series of books, perfect till-reads, combine satirical observation and absurdism. But what kind of nostalgia titillation is going on? And should they be better?</p><p>Arriving as the latest addition to the outlandishly popular Ladybird series for adults is <em>How It Works: The Dad</em>. “Laurie hates fishing so he only goes once a week. He comes here for the peace and quiet, but the water is a bit too noisy. ‘Shhhh,’ says Laurie to the ripples.” Dads tut and forget, they go to work to escape the noise of the children, they do the mildly comic things that dads do.</p><p>The high concept comedy book is often not particularly funny, and often isn’t meant to be: it has been devised as a&nbsp;“till read”, viz, a book you pick up because it’s right under your nose. With little thought going into your purchase of “Dos and Don’ts for Wives or Husbands”, you’re deliberately not saying anything very profound about the intended recipient, or your relationship to them (let’s take it as given that you would no sooner buy a till read for yourself than you would treat yourself to some chrysanthemums from a petrol station). Rather, you simply wish your giftee well; it is like a thick greeting card.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/12/ladybird-the-dad-review-zoe-williams">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How the first world war liberated women's wardrobes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/13/how-the-first-world-war-liberated-womens-wardrobes</link>
      <description><p>The Fashion and Freedom exhibition looks at the way clothes restricted women before the war – and shows how lines and silhouettes relaxed during the conflict as women entered the workplace</p><p>There were many upsides to Britain’s victory in the first world war – most notably peace, albeit of a temporary sort, in Europe. Less often noted is how the war liberated women from their corsets and full skirts when they were drafted in to run the country while the men were dying in muddy ditches across northern France. After finding that you can’t conduct a bus or forge steel in a floor-length silk day dress very well with a full bustle, these emancipating women started to experiment with far more practical clothes and hairstyles as they carried out their new roles in society.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/13/how-the-first-world-war-liberated-womens-wardrobes">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Story of cities #42: Medellín escapes grip of drug lord to embrace radical urbanism</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/13/story-cities-pablo-escobar-inclusive-urbanism-medellin-colombia</link>
      <description><p>Twenty-five years ago, Medellín was the most dangerous city on earth. Yet its most infamous criminal, Pablo Escobar, also helped create the conditions that sparked an extraordinary revival – by taking the city to the brink of collapse </p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/cities/series/the-story-of-cities">Read more articles in the series here</a></li></ul><p>“I’d never been to that neighbourhood before. It was a new world to me.” The architect Luis Miguel Velez Wiesner is recalling the first time he set foot in Santo Domingo, one of Colombia’s most notorious favelas, when the Medellín cable car opened in 2004. “The first time, I felt like I was going to be kidnapped. Now it’s quite different – there are lots of places to eat and shop. It feels safe now.”</p><p>For intrepid residents such as Wiesner, stepping off the cable car to enter the once out of bounds “other side” of Medellín, was a seminal moment in the history of their city.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/13/story-cities-pablo-escobar-inclusive-urbanism-medellin-colombia">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/13/tantalisingly-close-is-solar-thermal-energy-ready-to-replace-coal-fired-power</link>
      <description><p>Australian projects are viable already – now the industry needs investors willing to take a risk on large-scale renewable energy </p><p>Companies working on large-scale solar thermal projects in Australia say they are tantalisingly close to achieving the dream of building plants big enough to replace coal-fired energy in Australia.</p><p>Experts speaking at the Australian Solar Energy Exhibition and Conference in Melbourne last week said the technology had been proven in other countries, and projects in Australia were viable, but the challenge was getting major investors to gamble on something new.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/13/tantalisingly-close-is-solar-thermal-energy-ready-to-replace-coal-fired-power">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>David Wojnarowicz: still fighting prejudice 24 years after his death</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/13/david-wojnarowicz-close-to-the-knives-a-memoir-of-disintegration-artist-aids-activist</link>
      <description><p>Best known for an image on a U2 album cover, the painter and photographer was was also an Aids activist whose message of defiance from the late 80s reverberates in American politics today</p><p>You might not be familiar with the American artist and activist <a href="https://www.visualaids.org/artists/detail/david-wojnarowicz">David Wojnarowicz</a>’s name, but if you’re of a certain age, you have probably seen at least one image by him. His photograph of buffalo tumbling off a cliff was used as the cover of <a href="http://www.u2.com/discography/index/album/albumId/4039">U2’s <em>One</em></a>, taking his art to a global audience a few months before his death in 1992 of Aids-related complications.</p><p>Wojnarowicz was only 37 when he died, but he left behind an extraordinary body of work, particularly considering the uncongenial circumstances of much of his short life. A refugee from a violent family, a former street kid and teen hustler, he grew up to become one of the stars of the febrile 1980s East Village art scene, alongside <a href="http://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/2003/kikismith/">Kiki Smith</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/goldin">Nan Goldin</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/nov/11/keith-haring-review-the-political-side-of-a-pop-art-legend">Keith Haring</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/basquiat">Jean-Michel Basquiat</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/13/david-wojnarowicz-close-to-the-knives-a-memoir-of-disintegration-artist-aids-activist">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How Silverstring Media  fought GamerGate and ADHD to make compelling games</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/silverstring-gamergate-adhd-compelling-games</link>
      <description><p>For four months, this Vancouver studio was at the centre of an internet maelstrom. But it had overcome bigger challenges </p><p><em>“Recent events have thrust our company under a spotlight …” </em>It was with those words, in September 2014, that Lucas J W Johnson, one of the founding members of Silverstring Media, began <a draggable="true" href="http://silverstringmedia.com/news/2014/9/1/intent-and-ideology">a blogpost about his company</a>. “Under a spotlight”, it turned out, was something of an understatement. Silverstring Media had been targeted by the burgeoning online movement GamerGate, a loose affiliation of Twitter, Reddit and game forums users claiming to expose and protest corruption in the video games media. The company was accused of being “corrupt” and “creepy”, supposedly pushing ideologies and cultish practices that worked towards taking “the fun out of video games”. Connections were established between Silverstring and the original GamerGate target <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jan/11/gamergate-a-brief-history-of-a-computer-age-war">Zoe Quinn</a>. Then everything snowballed.</p><p>“[GamerGaters] got it into their heads that Silverstring Media was a PR firm, and that as such we must have been behind a conspiracy to release a series of ‘<a href="http://kotaku.com/we-might-be-witnessing-the-death-of-an-identity-1628203079">gamers</a> <a href="http://dangolding.tumblr.com/post/95985875943/the-end-of-gamers">are</a> <a href="https://www.buzzfeed.com/josephbernstein/gaming-is-leaving-gamers-behind">dead</a>’ articles all at once from multiple different venues,” Johnson said. “As conspiracies do, that then spiralled into further corruption with the Digital Games Research Association (DiGRA), and eventually allegations that we work with the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (Darpa). We became ‘the final boss’ of GamerGate, responsible for all their woes.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/silverstring-gamergate-adhd-compelling-games">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The arsonists of Fort McMurray have a name | Martin Lukacs</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/true-north/2016/may/12/the-arsonists-of-fort-mcmurray-have-a-name</link>
      <description><p>Fossil fuel corporations are causing the climate change fuelling mega-fires – and they should be footing the bill for the devastation </p><p>As the fire that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/canada-wildfire-fort-mcmurray-saved-alberta-premier">ravaged Fort McMurray</a> finally moves past the city, and the province tallies the heartbreaking damage, a search will begin to discover the source of the destruction.</p><p>Investigators will comb the nearby forests for clues, tracing the fire’s path to what they call its “point of origin.” They’ll interview witnesses, collect satellite imagery, and rule out natural causes—much like the work of detectives.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/true-north/2016/may/12/the-arsonists-of-fort-mcmurray-have-a-name">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How Eurovision finally cracked America</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/how-eurovision-finally-cracked-america-justin-timberlake</link>
      <description><p>Fifty million US households will be able to watch Europe’s premier song contest live for the first time this weekend. And with Justin Timberlake also performing, is the show gearing up to include the US?</p><p>For the first time, Americans will be able to watch the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/eurovision">Eurovision</a> song contest live on TV this Saturday. But there will be no such thing as Worldvision to replace Eurovision, says Jon Ola Sand, the contest’s executive supervisor, putting to rest rumours about the rapid expansion of the hit show.</p><p>Eurovision has been going big on export. The format <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/21/eurovision-sbs-announces-plans-for-asia-pacific-version-of-song-contest">has been sold to the Asia Pacific region</a>, China is airing the show for the third year running and, as of this year, 50 million US homes will be able to watch live on the Logo channel following a deal between the European Broadcast Union (EBU) and Viacom.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/how-eurovision-finally-cracked-america-justin-timberlake">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'We are not the Brady Bunch': Empire and the power of family</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/empire-black-family-power-tv-fox</link>
      <description><p>Whether they’re feuding, backstabbing or singing in perfect harmony, the TV family have unshakeable bonds many African Americans can relate to</p><p>Whatever feelings you may have about <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/31/empire-season-two-return-fox">Empire</a> as a television series, one thing that is resolutely clear from episode to episode, is that it stands to represent the power of family – in particular, black family. The bond between the Lyons, whether they are manipulating each other, saying downright evil, abhorrent things to each other or singing in pitch perfect harmony, is utterly unbreakable. And while I admire and envy it, I also don’t entirely understand it. I was adopted as an infant into a white family, and reunited with my white birthmother when I was 11 years old (I didn’t reunite with my black birthfather until I was in my early 20s), after which I spent 20 years trying to straddle two families – neither of which I felt I belonged to or bonded with completely. As with any family, that did not prevent reprehensible behavior toward one another, but I have never known or felt the kind of loyalty that the Lyon family brings us every week.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/31/empire-season-two-return-fox">Fall of Empire: show's big return is a lesson on how not to run a record label</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/empire-black-family-power-tv-fox">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The inside story of Facebook’s biggest setback | Rahul Bhatia</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-free-basics-india-zuckerberg</link>
      <description><p>The social network had a grand plan to connect millions of Indians to the internet. Here’s how it all went wrong</p><p>Until Mark Zuckerberg arrived in a bright orange helicopter in October 2014, Chandauli had never seen a celebrity visitor. One of 44,795 villages in the state of Rajasthan, Chandauli is only three or four hours’ drive from Delhi, but it exists alone and forgotten, tucked away, a kilometre off a quiet highway. Last year, when a local boy used the internet to buy a used motorcycle, astonished villagers called him an online shopping hero.</p><p>Zuckerberg had come to see an experiment at work. Earlier that year, with its sights set on the forthcoming elections, the government had asked a foundation to help give Chandauli’s mostly Muslim villagers a digital education. And so, with uncommon haste, a small administrative building was turned into a community centre, where locals could learn how to access email and find information online. Soon, almost every household in the village had one person who knew how to use a computer.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-free-basics-india-zuckerberg">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>When it comes to interracial romances, the movies need to catch up</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/when-it-comes-to-interracial-romances-the-movies-need-to-catch-up</link>
      <description><p>Almost 50 years after Kirk and Uhura’s kiss on Star Trek, there are plenty of parts for black women - provided they want to play blue- or green-skinned aliens …</p><p>“Interspecies love is in the air!” enthuses <a href="http://teaser-trailer.com/warcraft-movie-anduin-lothar-and-garona-halforcen/">one movie fansite</a> at the prospect of the forthcoming Warcraft movie.</p><p>There’s a lot to get up to speed with in Warcraft. The original video games were so wildly popular that their community of players exceeds the population of Norway, and the <a href="http://wowwiki.wikia.com/wiki/Portal:Main">World of Warcraft wiki</a> has over 100,000 pages. For novices, it’s a fantasy world not far removed from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/lord-of-the-rings">Lord of the Rings</a> or Dungeons and Dragons: a realm of elves, dwarves, mythical creatures and medieval weaponry. Warcraft the movie revolves around Azeroth, a kingdom apparently ruled by European humans. Azeroth is invaded by orcs: hulking, relatively primitive ogres with overdeveloped lower canines. Rather than open arms, Azeroth greets these refugee orcs with medieval arms. “They’re beasts. They should all be destroyed,” says one character. It’s essentially a race war, although the battle lines are by no means cut and dried, so there’s still room for a bit of interspecies love.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/when-it-comes-to-interracial-romances-the-movies-need-to-catch-up">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Why council waiting lists are shrinking, despite more people in need of homes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/housing-network/2016/may/12/council-waiting-lists-shrinking-more-need-homes</link>
      <description><p>The number of families on lists for council housing has fallen because of stricter rules on who can apply</p><p>With worries about the precariousness and affordability of housing in the private rented sector, thousands of households each year apply to join local social housing registers. </p><p> The number of people on waiting lists for council housing stands at 1,240,855 in England, while i<a draggable="true" href="http://www.gov.scot/Topics/Statistics/Browse/Housing-Regeneration/HSfS/HousingLists">n Scotland, 173,587 applicants</a> are on local authority waiting lists, with demand in some areas far higher: there are 24,909 applicants in the city of Edinburgh. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/housing-network/2016/may/12/council-waiting-lists-shrinking-more-need-homes">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Skepta: Konnichiwa review – rhymes that are dextrous, sharp and very British</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/skepta-konnichiwa-review-boy-better-know-album-of-the-week</link>
      <description><p>The architect of grime’s resurgence might have an eye on the US market, but he’s a distinctively, winningly English rapper<br></p><p>It features five singles – two of them silver-certified hits – guest appearances from A$AP Mob’s Young Lord and A$AP Nast and a collaboration with Pharrell Williams, but the most telling track on <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/06/10-things-we-learned-from-skeptas-konnichiwa">Skepta’s fourth album</a> might well be one that contains no music at all. As a tense bit of old-fashioned grime called Corn on the Curb unexpectedly ends – Skepta apparently forgetting the lyrics midway through a line, the sparse musical backing grinding to a halt – it’s replaced by the sound of a phone call between Skepta and fellow rapper Chip. The former sounds despondent, which comes as something of a surprise.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/dec/21/shutdown-skepta-best-track-of-2015-grime">The best track of 2015: Shutdown by Skepta</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/skepta-konnichiwa-review-boy-better-know-album-of-the-week">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/grime">Grime</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/hip-hop">Hip-hop</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/popandrock">Pop and rock</category>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/audio/2016/may/12/refugees-and-the-european-union-politics-weekly-podcast</link>
      <description><p>Patrick Kingsley, Alex Duval Smith and Jennifer Rankin join Tom Clark to discuss Europe’s response to the refugee crisis on its southern shores; the EU’s deal with Turkey and the future of the continent’s asylum system</p><p>Last year, more than a million refugees came across Europe’s borders. European countries first scrambled to provide shelter, then provided onward transport and eventually began to erect fences.</p><p>Now a deal with Turkey appears to have slowed the influx of migrants into Greece.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/audio/2016/may/12/refugees-and-the-european-union-politics-weekly-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>
