    <item>
      <title>Bristol, Ghana, Jamaica and back: my trip around the Atlantic slave triangle</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/12/selina-thompson-salt-mayfest-atlantic-slave-triangle</link>
      <description><p>She’s made hair weaves from family photos and dresses out of cake. Now Selina Thompson has criss-crossed the Atlantic ocean on a freight ship to bash a giant rock of salt to bits – and it’s all inspired by her grandma</p><p>Bending over the sink in her cramped, windowless cabin, halfway across the giant watery grave of the Atlantic, Selina Thompson washes her bras with cold, soapy hands. Months later, bending over a giant block of salt in the Arnolfini Gallery on the banks of Bristol’s former docks, she slowly smashes them into tiny crystals with her hot, sweat-soaked fists. <br></p><p>Formerly known for making a dress out of cake and a giant weave out of plastic fruit and family photos, Thompson decided to retrace the journey of the Atlantic slave triangle earlier this year. In travelling by freight from Britain to Ghana to Jamaica and back, she would put her body through a historical journey – and then make a show about it. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/12/selina-thompson-salt-mayfest-atlantic-slave-triangle">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What does it take to make a career out of brewing beer?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/beer-brewing-career-brewpubs-uk</link>
      <description><p>The rise of the brewpub shows no sign of stopping. Ahead of a members’ event in Cambridge, we hear from two head brewers</p><p>“For me, everything came together at the right time,” says Mark Burton, the head brewer at the <a draggable="true" href="http://www.thecambridgebrewhouse.com/">Cambridge Brew House</a>. “The company I was working for went into administration, I needed to make money immediately, so I turned my garage into a brewery and started selling to Cambridge free houses. I did that for a couple of years and then this job came up.”</p><p>Late last year, <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/news/britain-becomes-brewing-powerhouse">the government declared</a> that Britain was a “brewing powerhouse”, with three breweries opening a week. The <a draggable="true" href="http://www.beerandpub.com/">British Beer and Pub Association</a> (BBPA) estimates that by the end of 2015, there were about 1,800 breweries in the UK. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/beer-brewing-career-brewpubs-uk">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Obama banana 'jokes' show Soviet-era racism remains alive in Russia</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/little-obama-jokes-soviet-era-racism-remains-alive-in-russia</link>
      <description><p>A chocolate bar named ‘Little Obama’ is the latest in a string of offensive images triggered by political tensions</p><p>At the Slavitsa ice cream factory in Russia’s Republic of Tatarstan a decision has been made <a href="http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/russian-company-halts-little-obama-ice-cream-production/569083.html">to discontinue</a> one of its chocolate brands.</p><p>This ordinarily wouldn’t be news, except that these ice cream bars were named after <a href="https://viewer.gutools.co.uk/us-news/barack-obama">Barack Obama</a> and their launch elicited allegations of racism and anti-Americanism from the international community. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/little-obama-jokes-soviet-era-racism-remains-alive-in-russia">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Oakland city guide: what to see plus the best bars, hotels and restaurants</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/oakland-california-holiday-guide-usa</link>
      <description><p>The city across the bay has shed its inferiority complex and offers plenty of reasons to visit. In fact, you can now skip San Francisco altogether, and fly to Oakland direct from the UK</p><p>Oakland is changing fast. Once known merely as San Francisco’s rough-and-tough neighbour – the birthplace of the Black Panther movement and home of the Hell’s Angels – it is rapidly becoming the most fashionable place in northern California. Those who can’t afford the tech-boom prices across the Bay are making their home in the city and, greeted by an array of new restaurants and bars, a thriving arts scene, and a strong sense of energy and community. Gertrude Stein might have said about her childhood hometown that “There is no there there”, but, these days, Oakland’s residents and visitors are more likely to shout “Come here here!”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/12/oakland-california-holiday-guide-usa">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>How can I provide guests with Wi-Fi without giving them my password?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2016/may/12/how-can-i-provide-guests-with-wi-fi-without-giving-them-my-password</link>
      <description><p>Noel intends to register on AirBnB and wants to offer porn-free internet access without giving away all his security details</p><p><em>I intend to register on AirBnB and I’d like to know how to share my fibre optic internet connection safely, without giving out the main Wi-Fi password. I believe some routers have guest access features, but not the one I use: a BT Home Hub 3. I am also thinking about OpenDNS as an additional option to screen out pornography etc. I am open to buying another router if necessary.</em> <strong>Noel</strong></p><p>This is a topic that should interest people renting out their homes and small businesses that want to offer clients free Wi-Fi access – I wish my dentist did, for example.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2016/may/12/how-can-i-provide-guests-with-wi-fi-without-giving-them-my-password">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Eurovision fans: what do you make of the EU referendum?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/eurovision-fans-what-do-you-make-of-the-eu-referendum</link>
      <description><p>If you’re a massive fan of Europe’s song contest, we want to know your view on the UK’s upcoming referendum on EU membership<br></p><p>Much like the European Court of Human Rights, Eurovision doesn’t have much to do with the EU. If the UK votes for Brexit in June, its continuing place in the international song contest will be assured, not least because Britain is one of the “big five” Eurovision countries who contribute the most funding to the event.</p><p>Nevertheless. Founded by the European Broadcasting Union back in 1956, Eurovision is a symbol of pan-European cultural celebration, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/11/graham-norton-is-right-australias-participation-in-eurovision-is-stupid">even if they let Australia take part nowadays.</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/eurovision-fans-what-do-you-make-of-the-eu-referendum">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Share your recommendations in the comments and our reader will pick the best eligible songs in a playlist next week<br></p><p>This week we want to hear your songs on the theme of power.     <item>
      <title>What do migrants think about ONS immigration figures?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/what-do-migrants-think-about-ons-immigration-figures</link>
      <description><p>New figures from the UK’s statistics agency have raised concerns that the government has underestimated the number of people entering the country</p><p>Today, <a href="https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/internationalmigration/articles/noteonthedifferencebetweennationalinsurancenumberregistrationsandtheestimateoflongterminternationalmigration/2016#introduction">analysis from the Office of National Statistics (ONS) explores</a> whether or not the UK’s official migration statistics have underestimated the number of people entering the country.</p><p>It finds a big gap between official figures (which suggest 257,000 migrants came to the UK between September 2014 and 2015) and the number of EU migrants registering for National Insurance numbers (630,000 over the same period). <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/what-do-migrants-think-about-ons-immigration-figures">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Eurovision song contest: share your favourite memories</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/eurovision-2016-share-your-favourite-memories</link>
      <description><p>Ahead of Eurovision 2016, we’d like to hear about your fondest memories of previous song contests, and what hopes you have for your favourite this year</p><p>The 61st Eurovision song contest takes place in Stockholm on Saturday. The Swedish public can thank Måns Zelmerlöw for getting the chance to host the event for a third time, after his song <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5sGOwFVUU0I">‘Heroes’</a> triumphed in Vienna last year. Australia have been invited to the party once again, but this time around they face a nervy semi-final ahead of the main event. Greece are already out after semi-final elimination, the first time they are absent from the final since 2000. United Kingdom’s hopes of bettering last year’s 24th place rest with duo<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JX7e8DMT-hQ"> Joe and Jake</a>, both previous contestants on The Voice. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/08/eurovision-2016-latex-chiffon-politics-joe-jake">Eurovision song contest 2016: latex, chiffon and a little bit of politics</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/eurovision-2016-share-your-favourite-memories">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/06/euro-2016-what-hopes-do-you-have-for-your-team</link>
      <description><p>Ahead of the tournament we’d like to hear from football fans across Europe about what expectations you have for your team</p><p>France will kick off Euro 2016 against Romania at the Stade de France in exactly five weeks’ time. The tournament hosts are hoping to win the European Championship for a third time, while holders Spain aim to bounce back from their disappointing World Cup showing two years ago. <br></p><p>With 24 teams competing across 10 venues in nine French cities, football fever is likely to grip the entire nation.       <description><p>Johnny Cash, Black Sabbath and Morrissey accompany our reader on a journey into sin<br></p><p><em>Below is this week’s playlist – picked by <a href="https://profile.theguardian.com/user/id/14935010">a reader</a> from the comments on <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/readers-recommend-share-your-songs-about-sinners">last week’s blog</a>. Thanks for your suggestions. Read more about the weekly format of the Readers Recommend series at the end of the piece.</em></p><p>Who is a sinner?     <item>
      <title>What was the difference between Jason Koumas and Steven Gerrard? Not talent</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/in-bed-with-maradona/2016/may/12/jason-koumas-steven-gerrard-liverpool-tranmere</link>
      <description><p>As <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/sep/19/steven-gerrard-liverpool-football-interview-donald-mcrae">Steven Gerrard said goodbye to Liverpool</a> as a legend last year, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/apr/25/tranmere-cheltenham-relegated-conference-shrewsbury-plymouth">Jason Koumas was being relegated</a> to the fifth tier. The former team-mates were equally gifted but one won the Champions League and the other never played in a final. Why?</p><p>By <a href="https://twitter.com/leoncbarton">Leon Barton</a> for <a href="http://inbedwithmaradona.com/">In Bed With Maradona</a>, of the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/series/guardian-sport-network">Guardian Sport Network</a></p><p>When Liverpool and the Premier League said goodbye to Steven Gerrard a year ago, there was an avalanche of tributes in the media. It got me thinking about Gerrard’s old friend Jason Koumas, who, in contrast, was relegated from the Football League with Tranmere Rovers around the same time. Someone had to, I suppose. </p><p>I realise it might seem ludicrous to lump a man who won the Champions League, Uefa Cup, two FA Cups, three League Cups and represented England 114 times (encompassing six major tournaments) into the same introduction as a man who never won a trophy – or even played in a final – and played just 34 times for Wales, only once getting anywhere near to an international tournament before ultimately failing. But whenever I read or heard another eulogy for Liverpool’s departing captain, it brought to mind something my cousin – who played alongside Koumas as a youth team player at Tranmere – told me a few years earlier: “Jason had more ability than Steven Gerrard. The problem was ability was all he had.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/in-bed-with-maradona/2016/may/12/jason-koumas-steven-gerrard-liverpool-tranmere">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Air pollution: how does it affect you?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-how-does-it-affect-you</link>
      <description><p>With new WHO data <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-rising-at-an-alarming-rate-in-worlds-cities">shedding light on the severity of the problem</a>, we want to hear from readers across the globe on their experiences of air pollution<br></p><p>More than 80% of people living in urban areas where air pollution is monitored are exposed to air quality levels that excede World Health Organisation limits, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-rising-at-an-alarming-rate-in-worlds-cities">according to the latest urban air quality data released by the agency.</a></p><p>The data suggests populations in low-income cities are particularly under threat from the effects of air pollution.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-how-does-it-affect-you">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Wearing heels at work? Share stories of dress code discrimination</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/careers/2016/may/12/wearing-heels-at-work-share-stories-of-dress-code-discrimination</link>
      <description><p>Following news that Nicola Thorp was sent home from work for refusing to wear heels, we want to hear your stories of unfair company dress codes</p><p>Nicola Thorp says she was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/11/receptionist-sent-home-pwc-not-wearing-high-heels-pwc-nicola-thorp">sent home from her job</a> as a receptionist for PwC after refusing to wear heels. Thorp, who claims she was laughed at when she said the demand was discriminatory, told BBC Radio London: “I was expected to do a nine-hour shift on my feet escorting clients to meeting rooms. I said I just won’t be able to do that in heels.”</p><p>Lots of workplaces have dress codes, so have you experienced something similar? Is there a strict dress code in your office? Is it fair? Have you ever been called out on your outfit? Tell us your stories.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/careers/2016/may/12/wearing-heels-at-work-share-stories-of-dress-code-discrimination">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>'The BBC belongs to the public, not the government': readers defend the corporation</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/11/bbc-white-paper-john-whittingdale</link>
      <description><p>Ahead of a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/08/bbc-licence-fee-government-top-slicing-white-paper">John Whittingdale’s white paper on its future</a>, our readers rally round the corporation in its current form – with some caveats<br></p><p>Ahead of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/10/bbc-white-paper-conservative-mps-independence">Thursday’s white paper</a>, which could change the BBC as we know it, emotions have been stirred amid fears the government will erode the corporation’s editorial independence.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/09/bbc-charter-renewal-government-white-paper-scheduling-pay">BBC charter renewal: the main sticking points</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/11/bbc-white-paper-john-whittingdale">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Previewing the Football League play-offs: how the 12 clubs have fared in the past</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/the-agony-and-the-ecstasy/2016/may/11/football-league-play-offs-championship-league-one-two</link>
      <description><p>How will Brighton respond after their disappointment against Middlesbrough? Will Accrington Stanley recover after falling short on the last day of the season? And will Portsmouth improve on their result against Leicester City in 1993?</p><p>By <a href="https://twitter.com/rcfoster">Richard Foster</a> for <a href="http://www.ockleybooks.co.uk/books/browse-by-category/product/17-the-agony-the-ecstasy-a-comprehensive-history-of-the-football-league-play-offs">The Agony and the Ecstasy</a> of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/series/guardian-sport-network">Guardian Sport Network</a></p><p>An uncertain path lies ahead for fans of the dozen clubs preparing for the play-offs: a path strewn with undulations and plenty of twists and turns. There is nothing straightforward about earning promotion this way. It has become known for a particularly acute brand of cruelty for almost 30 years and emotions will be laid bare in the coming weeks. Here we take a look at how the clubs involved have fared in their previous play-offs appearances.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/the-agony-and-the-ecstasy/2015/nov/23/football-league-play-offs-agony-ecstasy">Chelsea, a curse and Tony Cascarino: lesser-known facts about the play-offs</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/the-agony-and-the-ecstasy/2016/may/11/football-league-play-offs-championship-league-one-two">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Waiters reveal what they really think about tipping</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/11/waiters-reveal-what-they-really-think-about-tipping</link>
      <description><p>A review highlights serious failings in how tips are managed by some businesses. Here, we ask waiters for the inside story on service charge<br></p><p>Did you know that there is no legal requirement for restaurants to give tips to staff?</p><p>It’s a fact that’s <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/tips-gratuities-cover-and-service-charges-proposals-for-further-action">covered in a government-led review</a>, released earlier this month, in which workers, employers and customers were asked their views on the tipping process. Off the back of it, ministers said they were keen to change rules and make sure low-paid workers get the money left for them by grateful customers. They have announced a <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/news/government-takes-action-on-tipping-practices-to-secure-a-fair-deal-for-workers">two-month consultation</a> on proposals that the government said would stamp out unfairness.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/11/waiters-reveal-what-they-really-think-about-tipping">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Meet Tony Moran, the homeless boxer who became a world champion aged 42</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/behind-the-lines/2016/may/11/tony-moran-homeless-boxer-world-champion-aged-42</link>
      <description><p>Tony Moran says he has been ‘moulded by adversity’ but, after losing his job and finding refuge in homeless shelters, he can now call himself a world champion</p><p>By <a href="https://twitter.com/jwdrennan">Jonathan Drennan</a> for <a href="https://jdrennan13.wordpress.com/">Behind the Lines</a>, part of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/series/guardian-sport-network">Guardian Sport Network</a><br></p><p>Last month, 42-year-old Liverpudlian <a href="http://www.worldboxingfoundation.com/current-wbf-world-champions">Tony Moran won a cruiserweight boxing world title</a> in Glasgow. There were no TV cameras to witness the event, no tuxedoed guests at ringside and no promises of life-changing purses. The World Boxing Federation belt that was strapped to his waist is a symbol of a life devoted to overcoming adversity outside of the ropes.</p><p>For three years Moran has been homeless, not sleeping rough on the streets, but completely reliant on the generosity of his friends and family for a bed. In a cruel twist of fate, a kind man who spent most of his life working with the city’s homeless in shelters, found himself joining them looking for a place to stay. The cruiserweight worked three jobs to provide for his children and fund a burgeoning boxing career and he remembers his first night as a homeless man well. He spent it in the homeless shelter laundry room, trying to coax his 6ft 6in frame into a sleeping position on the cold floor. It was Christmas night.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/behind-the-lines/2016/may/11/tony-moran-homeless-boxer-world-champion-aged-42">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 13:17:02 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/behind-the-lines/2016/may/11/tony-moran-homeless-boxer-world-champion-aged-42</guid>

      </media:content>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/11/how-much-should-you-spend-on-a-wedding-gift</link>
      <description><p>A wedding guest has claimed that they were rebuked for not giving enough on a couple’s big day. Share your views on this<br></p><p>Picture this, you attend a wedding of a former colleague only to be contacted later because the newyweds feel (horror of horrors) that the gift you gave was not generous enough.</p><p>It’s a situation that an unnamed guest has claimed to have been in, posting the story to a forum on <a href="http://www.mumsnet.com/Talk/mumsnet_classics/2630932-Post-wedding-message-please-help-me-what-the-hell-do-I-say?pg=10">Mumsnet </a>asking for advice after she was told the £100 cheque she provided wasn’t enough.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/may/11/how-much-should-you-spend-on-a-wedding-gift">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Who should take Danny Welbeck's place in the England squad at Euro 2016?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/who-scored-blog/2016/may/10/danny-welbeck-england-euro-2016-carroll-deeney-defoe</link>
      <description><p>Andy Carroll, Troy Deeney or Jermain Defoe could play up front for England but Roy Hodgson may look to Theo Walcott, Michail Antonio, Andros Townsend, Marc Albrighton or Wilfried Zaha for more attacking options on the wing</p><p>By <a href="https://twitter.com/martinlaurence7">Martin Laurence</a> for <a href="http://www.whoscored.com/">WhoScored?</a>, part of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/series/guardian-sport-network">Guardian Sport Network</a></p><p>The <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/10/arsenal-danny-welbeck-out-months-knee-surgery-england-euro-2016">knee injury Danny Welbeck suffered</a> in Arsenal’s match against Manchester City has ruled him out of this summer’s European Championship, which is a significant blow to Roy Hodgson. While the 25-year old forward is far from prolific at club level, his international record is highly commendable and Welbeck has become a favourite of the England boss. He offers exceptional athleticism in attack but, as with other explosive, muscular players, his susceptibility to injury has hampered his career.</p><p>How Hodgson reacts to this setback will depend on the role he saw Welbeck occupying in his squad. Welbeck prefers to play as a central striker but Hodgson would have deployed him in a wide role, with the likes of Harry Kane, Jamie Vardy and Daniel Sturridge less flexible tactically. With three very good options to choose from in the No9 position, not to mention captain Wayne Rooney, Hodgson could opt to replace Welbeck with another player capable of fulfilling duties on the wing.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/who-scored-blog/2016/may/10/danny-welbeck-england-euro-2016-carroll-deeney-defoe">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Underworld webchat – your questions answered, on the Olympics, Batman and Born Slippy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/live/2016/may/09/underworld-webchat-barbara-barbara-we-face-a-shining-future</link>
      <description><p>Karl Hyde from Underworld joined us to answer your questions, about everything from how he writes lyrics to the greatness of Glasgow Barrowlands</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-11T13:15:19.451Z">2.15pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>We’ll leave the thanks to the man himself...</p><p>Thank you to everyone who's taken part in this. It's been interesting to talk to you in this way. My thanks to the speedy fingers that have translated my gibberish and I look forward to seeing you all out in the world soon.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-11T13:14:19.471Z">2.14pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><a href="https://profile.theguardian.com/user/id/14593714">Amaranthus</a> asks:</p><p><em>Now it is so easy to make and produce dance music, do you think the explosion of people making their own stuff (which has flooded the market) is now a negative for people looking for real quality tunes which are lost in a sea of mediocrity?</em></p><p>I think we've always been afloat in the sea of mediocrity, and that has inspired people to react to it. The underground is continually throwing up angry youth who react against the establishment or mediocrity - I would be more worried if the underground wasn't worried and pointing fingers. Then we really would be in trouble. What the ease of access to the recording process has done is to create a generic sound, therefore what I'm seeing now is a groudswell backlash to that, ie modular synthesis, instruments with knobs, strings, reeds, and an exploration in search of idiosyncrasy and personality. And it's working.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/live/2016/may/09/underworld-webchat-barbara-barbara-we-face-a-shining-future">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/underworld">Underworld</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>

      <title>What does the election of a Muslim mayor of London mean to you?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/09/what-does-the-election-of-a-muslim-mayor-of-london-mean-to-you</link>
      <description><p>Sadiq Khan is the first elected Muslim mayor of a Western capital city. We want to find out how the appointment is viewed from outside the UK</p><p>Sadiq Khan is the first directly-elected <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/07/uk-elections-2016-labour-prospects-shifting-political-faultlines">Muslim mayor of a Western capital city.</a> As the rest of Europe struggles with the rise of anti-immigration parties, Khan’s victory sends an important message. If you live outside of the UK, we want to hear what his appointment means to you.<br></p><p>Germany, Netherlands and Sweden have been trying to stem the rise in anti-immigration parties buoyed by Europe’s migration crisis and fears over Brussels and Paris styled terrorist attacks. In the current climate, the election of a Muslim mayor in a Western capital is significant . Could the same happen in your city or country?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/09/what-does-the-election-of-a-muslim-mayor-of-london-mean-to-you">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/09/share-your-views-on-the-future-of-the-bbc</link>
      <description><p>What do you think of the government’s handling of the public broadcaster? Do you agree with Gary Lineker?<br></p><p>As BBC stars attack the <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/08/bbc-licence-fee-government-top-slicing-white-paper">government’s white paper outlining plans for the corporation’s future</a>, we want to hear your views.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>Last week the Match of the Day presenter Gary Lineker called the culture secretary, John Whittingdale, a “chump” for making a joke that abolishing the BBC was a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/04/bbc-john-whittingdale-impartiality?CMP=share_btn_tw">“tempting prospect</a> – and he’s not the only high-profile figure to criticise the way the government is handling the institution.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/09/share-your-views-on-the-future-of-the-bbc">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>What do Greeks think of the latest austerity measures?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/09/what-do-greeks-think-of-the-latest-austerity-measures</link>
      <description><p>We want to hear from the people of Greece about plans to overhaul the country’s tax and pension system <br></p><p>Ποιες είναι απόψεις σας για το νέο ασφαλιστικό και φορολογικό νομοσχέδιο Θέλουμε να ακούσουμε από Έλληνες για το δεύτερο πακέτο φορολογικών μέτρων.</p><p>The toughest austerity measures yet <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/08/rioters-take-to-the-streets-ahead-of-greek-austerity-vote">have been approved in Greece amid a backdrop of rioting</a>. Greece’s coalition will now turn to the issue of debt relief on Monday at a crucial meeting of eurozone finance ministers. </p><p>Plans to overhaul the country’s tax and pension system, which amounts to cuts worth €5.4bn (£4.27bn), have been bitterly opposed by Greek citizens. Vassilis Papadopoulos, a young waiter, said of the proposals: “How can anyone survive on a national monthly pension of €384? How can a state function when over 25% of its population is unemployed?”. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/09/what-do-greeks-think-of-the-latest-austerity-measures">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Waiters, what do you really think about tipping?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/09/waiters-what-do-you-really-think-about-tipping</link>
      <description><p>There’s been plenty of stories of restaurants skimming tips from staff for admin fees. What happens where you work?<br></p><p>The government launched a review last year into tipping, looking at 150,000 businesses – from hospitality to leisure services. It followed news that dozens of restaurants were exposed for skimming tips from staff for administration fees.</p><p>So what did it find? <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/tips-gratuities-cover-and-service-charges-proposals-for-further-action">The results</a> came out at the beginning of May and three main changes were suggested. Firstly, the report said that it needs to be made clearer to consumers that tips are voluntary. Other proposals include <a href="https://www.buzzfeed.com/simonneville/13-things-you-may-not-know-about-tipping-in-restaurants?utm_term=.lmGBAXo6V#.hb3eBAP4O">that there needs to be more guarantees tips are given to workers and that the whole process becomes more open and transparent</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/09/waiters-what-do-you-really-think-about-tipping">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>We’re making a new tech podcast – and we need your help</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/09/were-making-a-new-tech-podcast-and-we-need-your-help</link>
      <description><p>After eight years of bringing Tech Weekly to your ears, we’re preparing a new podcast – it will be better, bigger, more human and ... it needs you! While we get everything ready, tell us the one thing about tech you’d like explained</p><p>We launched our technology podcast <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/series/techweekly">Tech Weekly</a> the year the first iPhone was released. Think about that. Most of us were still making calls on flip phones, MySpace was still relevant, and people were still renting DVDs from Blockbuster. That was eight years ago, and needless to say, Tech Weekly has come a long way.</p><p>We’ve covered topics such as <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/audio/2009/jan/20/tech-weekly-podcast-israel-gaza">how social media is used in Middle-Eastern conflicts</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/audio/2012/sep/05/tech-weekly-podcast-argentina-audio">President Obama’s Reddit AMA session</a>, and done deep dives into things like <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/audio/2015/nov/20/isis-islamic-state-internet-digital-technology">ISIS’ use of tech</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/audio/2016/apr/14/why-your-uber-ratings-more-important-than-you-think-tech-weekly-podcast">why your Uber rating is actually quite important</a>.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/09/were-making-a-new-tech-podcast-and-we-need-your-help">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Azealia Banks suspended from Twitter following racist attack on Zayn Malik</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/azealia-banks-suspended-twitter-racist-rant-zayn-malik</link>
      <description><p>The rapper’s latest Twitter feud saw her strike out at former One Direction star Malik with homophobic and racially charged slurs</p><p>Rapper <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/azealia-banks">Azealia Banks</a> has been suspended from Twitter following a series of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/azealia-banks-axed-uk-music-festival-zayn-malik-twitter">racially charged tweets</a> attacking singer and former One Direction star Zayn Malik.</p><p>After Banks accused Malik of copying a music video of hers for his single Like I Would, Malik tweeted “My @’s too good for you” – a reference to the fact that Banks had not directed the accusation at his account for him to see.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/azealia-banks-suspended-twitter-racist-rant-zayn-malik">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Woody Allen responds to Ronan Farrow: 'I never read anything about me'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/woody-allen-ronan-farrow-cannes-cafe-society-film</link>
      <description><p>The film-maker, at Cannes with his new film Café Society, spoke with press at a lunch about his son’s article and the rape joke made at his expense during the opening night ceremony</p><p>Woody Allen’s opening night film of the 69th Cannes film festival, Cafe Society, has been generally well-received by critics. But Wednesday’s kick-off to the event was by no means smooth for the 80-year-old film-maker.</p><p>The morning of the premiere, a piece by Ronan Farrow, Allen’s estranged son, ran in the Hollywood Reporter, restating his support for his stepsister, Dylan, who has in the past claimed Allen sexually assaulted her as a child. Later, in introducing the film at the Lumiere cinema, master of ceremonies Laurent Lafitte shocked the audience when he addressed a joke to Allen, saying: “It’s very nice that you’ve been shooting so many movies in Europe, even if you are not being convicted for rape in the US.” </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/woody-allen-ronan-farrow-cannes-cafe-society-film">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Labour supporter Terence Smith has been voted in as mayor of Goole, in east Yorkshire, on a 12-month term</p><p>At the age of 19, Terence Smith has become the UK’s youngest mayor.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/may/12/yukio-ninagawa-shakespeare-dies-aged-80</link>
      <description><p>Ninagawa, who won acclaim for a samurai-style Macbeth at the Edinburgh festival, had been suffering from pneumonia</p><p><a href="http://www.ninagawastudio.net/English/E-yukioninagawa.html">Yukio Ninagawa</a>, the world-renowned Japanese stage director known for his adaptations of Shakespeare, has died at a Tokyo hospital. He was 80.<br></p><p>Ninagawa debuted as a director in 1969 and gained international fame at the 1985 Edinburgh festival when he directed a samurai-style Macbeth in which the actors performed in Japanese kimono on a stage with a giant Buddhist altar.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/may/12/yukio-ninagawa-shakespeare-dies-aged-80">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Macklemore and Ryan Lewis: ‘Systemic racism isn’t going to get clicks’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/macklemore-ryan-lewis-systemic-racism-isnt-going-get-clicks</link>
      <description><p>Unrest in Ferguson led the duo to question their role in hip-hop. The result was White Privilege II, an examination of how white people view race. Will the pair’s soul-searching make fans assess their place in society, too?</p><p>The first sound recorded during this interview with Ben “Macklemore” Haggerty and Ryan Lewis tells you a lot about where their heads are right now. Before a word has been spoken, Haggerty lets out a cavernous yawn, one that threatens never to end. “Tired?” I ask as he slumps in front of me in a room backstage at the O2 in London. He nods&nbsp;back, the energy for words still beyond him.</p><p>There are obvious reasons why Haggerty might be knackered. He is currently six&nbsp;months into a world tour promoting the duo’s second studio album, This Unruly Mess I’ve Made, a tour which, if tonight’s show is anything to go by, requires every ounce of energy he can conserve: just over an hour from now, he will be performing slam-dunk leaps across the stage for the venue’s 10,000-strong crowd. Haggerty also recently became a father for the first time, a calling to which he is so determined to give his all that this morning he got up early and took his daughter Sloane on a tour of London.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/macklemore-ryan-lewis-systemic-racism-isnt-going-get-clicks">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/macklemore-ryan-lewis-systemic-racism-isnt-going-get-clicks</guid>

    <item>
      <title>Margo Price: ‘Country music is about divorce, drinking and jail’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/margo-price-country-music-is-about-divorce-drinking-and-jail</link>
      <description><p>The outlaw Nashville singer worried she’d be singing to empty bars her whole life until Jack White heard the songs on Midwest Farmer’s Daughter</p><p>A new sticker has appeared on the back of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/jul/23/jack-white-third-man-records-books-publishing-wing">Third Man Records</a> minivan, which is blocking the driveway of Margo Price’s home in Inglewood, East Nashville: “You puke, you pay!”</p><p>“I don’t know if it’s for us or another band,” the 33-year-old singer says, before apologising profusely. She drove back from a show at 3am the night before so she could be home when her five-year-old son Judah woke up this morning. She’s lost her voice, hasn’t slept a full night in weeks, and her grass is so overgrown that it broke the lawnmower. Her car is littered with the debris of a fishing trip, which she quickly tidies away.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/margo-price-country-music-is-about-divorce-drinking-and-jail">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/country">Country</category>

    <item>
      <title>Michael Ratner obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/law/2016/may/12/michael-ratner-obituary</link>
      <description>US human rights lawyer who challenged the detention without charge of hundreds of prisoners in Guantánamo Bay<p>In the years following 9/11, Michael Ratner, who has died of cancer aged 72, emerged as one of America’s foremost human rights lawyers. He galvanised 500 US lawyers of various political persuasions to challenge the legality of holding hundreds of Muslim men, arrested around the world, without charge or trial in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/guantanamo-bay" title="">Guantánamo Bay</a>. He served as president and later president emeritus of the New York-based <a href="http://ccrjustice.org/" title="">Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR)</a>, founded in 1966 by the leftwing lawyer <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/05/obituaries/william-kunstler-76-dies-lawyer-for-social-outcasts.html" title="">William Kunstler</a> and others who represented the civil rights movement in the southern states in its most challenging years. Ratner worked there for 40 years, and his leadership made CCR the focal point for the lawyers who went to Guantánamo to represent unknown prisoners from a dozen countries, and then a leading voice for closing the detention camp.</p><p>As co-counsel in the landmark US supreme court case <a href="http://www.britannica.com/event/Rasul-v-Bush" title="">Rasul v Bush</a> in 2004, Ratner and his team won Guantánamo prisoners the right to test the legality of their detentions in court. Disillusioned and angry at the politicised judiciary that made the cases fail on appeal over and over again until the present, Ratner worked tirelessly against the administration’s lawyers. Until the end of his life he was working for the cases that were among those that outraged and saddened him most – the continuing detention of Guantánamo prisoners cleared by the US military and security services years before, but still imprisoned in defiance of international law and the US constitution.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/law/2016/may/12/michael-ratner-obituary">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/law/human-rights">Human rights</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/law/law">Law</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/guantanamo-bay">Guantánamo Bay</category>

      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:03:16 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/law/2016/may/12/michael-ratner-obituary</guid>

    <item>
      <title>Crystal Pite: 'In ballet, girls are less likely to be prized for being mavericks'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/may/12/crystal-pite-girls-ballet-choreographer-prized-mavericks</link>
      <description><p>Ahead of her new work, which is based on a profound real-life tragedy, the sought-after choreographer discusses dancing with William Forysthe, motherhood and why there are so few women at the top of her profession</p><p>“You’re not stretching your face enough”, explains <a href="http://www.kiddpivot.org/company/">Crystal Pite</a>, patiently. She demonstrates with a lop-sided grimace that distorts her rather beautiful, open features into a kind of agitated question mark. It’s not the standard rehearsal note from a choreographer to their dancers, but the eight men and women in the studio mimic Pite’s expression as they dance, and an unsettling new energy comes into their bodies. You can feel a shift in the atmosphere of the room.<br></p><p>It’s this close attention to detail, this hunting down of the precise physical image, that gives Pite’s work its unusually poetic quality. It’s also key to her passion to communicate ideas, emotions and even stories through her choreography. From works like the epic, elemental <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/nov/02/see-the-music-hear-the-dance-sadlers-wells-thomas-ades-review">Polaris</a> to The Statement – the study of conflict, which I’m watching her create for <a href="http://www.ndt.nl/en/home.html">Nederlands Dans Theater</a> – Pite’s instinct is always to reach through the steps for some direct connection with her audience.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/may/12/crystal-pite-girls-ballet-choreographer-prized-mavericks">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ori Gersht's best photograph: a bullet hitting a pomegranate at 1,600 frames per second</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/11/ori-gershts-best-photograph-a-bullet-hitting-a-pomegranate-at-1600-frames-per-second</link>
      <description><p>‘I used a pomegranate instead of a quince – since pomegranates explode like grenades’</p><p>This image references a 1602 Baroque still life by Juan Sánchez Cotán titled <a href="http://www.wga.hu/frames-e.html?/html/s/sanchez/cotan/stillife.html" title="">Quince, Cabbage, Melon and Cucumber</a>. It’s a very cerebral painting, because he was trying to create a sense of perfect static balance. It must have taken an awfully long time. My photograph was&nbsp;an act of destruction, taken at an unthinkable speed. I decided to use a&nbsp;pomegranate, instead of a quince, because a pomegranate would explode&nbsp;like a grenade.</p><p>I took it after a long period in Ukraine, photographing the landscapes my grandfather-in-law would have seen when he survived the Holocaust. Soon after, my son was born. I was travelling a&nbsp;lot, and I think I became more introverted. This image came from a need to produce a moment of destruction that&nbsp;would also be a moment&nbsp;of creation.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/11/ori-gershts-best-photograph-a-bullet-hitting-a-pomegranate-at-1600-frames-per-second">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/photography">Photography</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/artanddesign">Art and design</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 16:01:18 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/11/ori-gershts-best-photograph-a-bullet-hitting-a-pomegranate-at-1600-frames-per-second</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/4a7b16262528ab4039e7d1a26b1cd64d0ce1acd4/0_368_4000_2400/4000.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=70a2ff4dae3edbf789222ff7363216e1">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Ori Gersht</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/4a7b16262528ab4039e7d1a26b1cd64d0ce1acd4/0_368_4000_2400/4000.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=d7cb6416359f5e76cedcf2799320ad5a">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Ori Gersht</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <dc:creator>Interview by Tom Seymour</dc:creator>
      <dc:date>2016-05-11T16:01:18Z</dc:date>
    </item>
